talk.start.para: âAs I was saying prior to question time, after winning office the New Zealand Prime Minister, Helen Clark, partially re-regulated the labour market. Even so, only a small list of minimum entitlements were included: a minimum adult wage, three weeks annual leave, 11 paid annual holidays, five days sick leave, three days bereavement leave and up to 13 weeks paid maternity leave. With this slight re-regulation, New Zealand still has a far less regulated system than the Australian system will be after our reforms come into place.

speech.para: If we go across to the other side of the world, to the United Kingdom, where the Labour Prime Minister inherited a system from a Conservative Prime Minister, we hear a similar story being told. The United Kingdom industrial relations system is also far more deregulated than ours will be, and they are reaping the benefits of those reforms, which the Labour Prime Minister, Tony Blair, accepted upon winning office. In 1997 Tony Blair said in his first speech to the United Kingdom Trade Union Congress:

quote.para: We are not going back to the days of industrial warfare, strikes without ballots, mass and flying pickets and secondary action ...
â¦Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â â¦Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â â¦

... fairness at work starts with the chance of a job in the first place, because if we ... do not make Britain a country of successful businesses, a country where people want to set up and expand and a country that has the edge over our competitors, then we are betraying those we represent ...

speech.para: The British Prime Minister, Tony Blair, recognises that a job is a great start in life and, through a job, people can work their way out of any potential welfare dependency. By getting that first step into the labour market, various other career options can emerge for the person who was originally unemployed.

In the United Kingdom the state has largely kept out of industrial relations, under the principle of âvoluntarismâ. Relatively recent changes have made a range of workplace relations matters subject to statutory regulation. Unlike Australia, the United Kingdom has never had awards. Since 1997, the Low Pay Commission has set the minimum wage in the UK. In many ways this body is a forerunner to the proposed Australian Fair Pay Commission included in this bill. There is, however, one major difference: the British government reserves the right to reject decisions made by the Low Pay Commission. This government through our reforms will not be able to reject the decisions of the new Fair Pay Commission. It is obvious that throughout this debate a lot of huff and puff has taken placeâ(Time expired)

talk.start.para: âIt does seem a rather bizarre way to begin my contribution, but it will take only a minute for me to say that I am amazed on another matter to see the Attorney-General come into this place, introduce legislation of profound import and take just 10 minutes to read his speech into the Hansard. I must say that, given the importance of that legislation and the debate it has generated, it is consistent with the pattern that we have seen in this Workplace Relations Amendment (Work Choices) Bill 2005 that the parliament is treated with such contempt.

speech.para: When you are making momentous changes of this kind, it is incumbent upon ministers to take the parliament seriously, at least for public display, even if they do regard the parliament as a rubber stamp for the executive. We have seen this pattern repeated over and over again, and it is becoming very galling not just for members of the opposition but for the community at large to see their elected representatives held in such disdain. I believe that Australians generally would want to see this government held to account on this bill, as on others, for setting aside the usual procedures and protocols of this parliament.

talk.start.para: (Hon. IR Causley)âOrder! It being 4.30 pm, I propose the question:

motion.para: That the House do now adjourn.

debate.para: I remind the member for Fremantle that she was way out of order.

talk.start.para: âI was not, Mr Deputy Speaker. I was speaking to the bill.

âWe learned this week that the bill for taxpayers from the governmentâs industrial relations advertising campaign was $50 million, not the $30 million or $40 million the Prime Minister had fessed up to on radioâ$50 million and rising; over a million dollars a day being spent. With apologies to Winston Churchill, never before in the history of government advertising has so much money been hosed up against a wall by so few in so short a time. Fifty million dollars to produce full-page ads which say, âAustralia cannot afford to stand stillâ! This is not information: information would be something like telling Australians how to recognise the symptoms of bird flu; this is propaganda. And with the government so cheerfully taking a cigarette lighter to taxpayersâ funds have come the stories of excess, like the man who was paid $6,000 just for a morningâs work as an extra on a set. He was only going there to drop off his kids, he was not even used, and he says there were nine others like himâ$60,000 of taxpayersâ money straight down the gurgler. Then there were the call centre operators who were also paid to do nothing because they were rostered on a full six hours before the governmentâs ads even went to air!

speech.para: Taxpayers around Australia are no doubt wondering how such excesses can possibly happen. In the case of the advertising agency fees, it is all too simple. The ad agency get a percentage of everything they spend. In the case of this contract, the amount is a secret. But typically it is 10 to 15 per cent, so the more they spend the more they makeâbeautiful! And just who is the advertising agency with the contract for this $50 million IR campaign? It is none other than Dewey Horton, one of whose principals, Ted Horton, also does the Liberal Partyâs campaign advertising. Did the contract go out to tender? No. Could other agencies bid for it? No. Is the contract secret? Yes. Who awarded it? That would be the Ministerial Committee on Government Communications, a committee of Liberal Party MPs and ministers located deep within the bowels of the Prime Ministerâs department.

Ted Horton is making a great deal of money from this campaign, as he no doubt has done from his previous work. And some people who make a lot of money sometimes do not want to pay all the tax that is owing on it. I am aware of reports that a Melbourne based advertising agency has provided documents to the tax office following a query by the tax office concerning payments to Mr Horton. I have also heard reports that Mr Horton has made payments to international accounts when working for overseas clients. The government must investigate this matter and tell the Australian people whether the Australian Taxation Office has sought documents from Ted Horton or any of his former employers or former or current clients as part of the high net worth individuals investigation or other routine inquiries. Were any of those queries or documents related to the issue of offshore payments to Mr Horton for work done either in Australia or overseas? Has Mr Horton been investigated by the tax office as part of its high net worth individuals investigation? If so, what are the results of that investigation?

The Australian people are also entitled to some transparency surrounding the awarding of advertising contracts by the Ministerial Committee on Government Communications. The Clerk of the Senate, Harry Evans, criticised the lack of openness concerning these contracts and said they contained the potential for corruption. He was absolutely right to do so. It is too cute by half that this massive, lucrative contract given out by Liberal Party insiders just happens to go to the Liberal Partyâs own advertising team.

This week we also learned that Ted Horton had taken on Mark Pearson for the IR advertising splurge. Mr Pearson and Mr Horton work together on Liberal Party campaigns. Mark Pearson is no stranger to Liberal government largesse: he made a handy little $400,000 out of the GST ad campaign. The public are entitled to know how much Mr Pearson and Mr Horton are making out of taxpayers this time. The public want to know how these contracts are awarded. They want to see the documents. They want to know what checks the government has to ensure contracts do not go to tax avoiders. It is time to clean up this rotten insider dealing. Make the advertising contracts subject to the governmentâs procurement policy and put them out for open tender and assessment on their merits, not on the basis of who has done the most to help the Liberal Party.

talk.start.para: âToday in the parliament I spoke on the Workplace Relations Amendment (Work Choices) Bill 2005. I was very delighted to speak on that because it is all about securing the future prosperity of this country and bringing jobs to the young people of Australia and indeed all Australians, particularly those Australians who live in my electorate of Ryan. It is a momentous bill and it is all about business. I want to continue that theme this afternoon but particularly in relation to the tourism industryâand I am delighted to see that the Minister for Small Business and Tourism is in the chamber as I speak. We have just heard the shadow minister for public accountability give another antibusiness diatribe. His contributions in this parliament are always wrapped in grubby attacks and below the belt verballing of companies that are doing legal business in this country.

speech.para: Tourism in this country is all about jobs and I want to refer to Lone Pine Koala Sanctuary in Fig Tree Pocket, which employs many Australians; indeed, many young Australians are employed there. Those at the sanctuary were delighted by the news this week about the prospects of receiving more Chinese tourists from mainland China, the Peopleâs Republic of China. Earlier this week the government announced that a significant number of Chinese will be able to come to this country, consistent with an agreement that the Australian government and the Chinese government have signed. The new agreement between the two governments, through the China National Tourism Administration, approved potentially 850 million to 900 million Chinese visiting this country. Of course, we do not expect that many to come here but we would be delighted with many hundreds of thousands coming, because they will continue to provide jobs in this country.

The Approved Destination Status schemeâthe ADS schemeâis a bilateral scheme which enables Chinese tourists to visit Australia on group tours. Australia was the first Western country to be designated as an approved destination for tourists from China. The new agreement was announced in China recently by Senator the Hon. Amanda Vanstone and very strongly supported by the Minister for Small Business and Tourism and her department:

quote.para: âThis new agreement will mean an additional 855 million Chinese citizens will now be eligible to apply for a tourist visa to Australia, growing the pool of potential tourists considerably,â Fran Bailey, Minister for Small Business and Tourism, said ...

speech.para: This country is experiencing enormous growth. China is a nation that we consider very important to our bilateral relations and, with a free trade agreement being discussed at the moment between the two countries, this further reflects the enormous potential for business and for commerce to grow between our businesspeople and those entrepreneurs in a mainland China. The minister for tourism went on:

quote.para: China is the new tourism tiger in the playground. Millions of middle class Chinese with cash to spend are looking to travel. Within three years, the Chinese market is forecast to be our second largest in terms of its contribution to the Australian economy.

speech.para: I am delighted to play a small part in fostering exchanges and visits between our two countries in terms of Chinese businesspeople coming to this country and also to provide opportunities for Australian businesses, including those in my Ryan electorate, to engage in commercial relationships in China.

China is currently the fifth largest source of tourists and it is forecast to be the second largest by 2013-14. Visitor arrivals from China are forecast to grow from 286,000âalmost 300,000âfor 2004-05 to in excess of 1.1 million within the decade. This is an average annual growth of 16.5 per cent. The real market value of Chinese visitors in 2005 is forecast to be some $1.5 billion and it is forecast to increase to $5.9 billion by 2014. This is good for Australians because it is going to contribute to providing jobs throughout the country for our young people. It is going to provide opportunities for those in hospitality and in retail. I am sure that the opposition would support the government in this endeavour, because it is all about providing jobs for people in this country and, in my case as the federal member for Ryan, providing as many opportunities as possible for people in Ryan to take on jobs. The hospitality sector, the retail sector and the tourism industry are very significant to this nationâs economy. I encourage all members of the parliament to speak very strongly about this policy, about this initiative and about this agreement because it is in the interests of all Australians. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI rise today to speak on behalf of the very many young people in this country who face a very limited choice because of the Howard governmentâs refusal to address the skills crisis in this countryâa skills crisis that is worsening all the time. This is the week in which we have seen the Howard government introducing its extreme attack on our industrial relations system. They want to strip workers of their rights and conditions and leave the most vulnerable unprotected in the workplace, and young Australians will be particularly at risk. I am very much concerned, particularly for the young people and, indeed, all the families within Richmond.

speech.para: The Prime Minster wants us to compete with low-wage economies like China and India by slashing Australian wages. This is economically irresponsible and will undermine our very way of life. Instead we need to compete with these economies by addressing our skills crisis and building the skills of Australian workersâthat is where our focus should be. We are facing a skills crisis because we have been subjected to nine long years of a Howard government that refuses to properly invest in vocational education and training. This incompetence is affecting so many people within my electorate of Richmond. Many locals have been telling me that they desperately want to get employment, they want to get skilled but they cannot as the courses are not available for them because the federal Howard government will not properly fund our TAFEs.

This decline in funding over the last nine years has meant that TAFEsâincluding those in my electorate of Richmondâare often forced to turn away potential students because there are no courses to place them in. I want to talk about some local examples, in particular Gregory Watts and Michael Gray. Both fellows want to upskill and get welding qualifications and, currently, the North Coast of New South Wales is suffering a skills shortage in metal fabrication and welding. Nearby there is a first-rate welding school at Wollongbar TAFE. So far, it sounds like Gregory and Michael are on the right track and making a good career decision. But they cannot actually get into a course at Wollongbar TAFE. Members might ask why it is they cannot get in there. They cannot because the Howard government is starving TAFEs of funds and, consequently, the welding school can open only during the day and not at night. Locals like Gregory and Michael, who have to work during the day to support themselves and their families, need to train at night and they cannot because that particular course is not available at night.

I understand there are at least another 30 locals in this same position, many of whom have spoken to me because they really want to be able to do this welding course at Wollongbar TAFE and they are not able to. I understand there are also many local businesses that actually want to pay to have their workers upskilled in this course at this TAFE and they cannot. So what is the situation that we find ourselves in here? We have a shortage of welders in this area. We have local businesses that are willing to pay for this particular staff training. On the North Coast, we have youth unemployment at over 30 per cent, which is a huge amount. We also have one of the best welding schools in the state. We have this absurd situation where this school is sitting idle at night because of a lack of funding from the short-sighted Howard government. These locals are unable to access that course. Instead this government wants to bring in apprentices from overseas to satisfy the skills crisis. What are we supposed to be saying to locals like Michael and Gregory? What we are saying is, âWeâre not going to bother training you; weâd rather give your job to someone from another country.â This is an absurd situation. I believe we need to train Australians first. In Richmond we need to train locals first, such as Michael and Gregory, who desperately want to do this training. We should not be importing apprentices and workers from overseas to be filling these positions; we need to be training and skilling our young people first.

In contrast, federal Labor has a blueprint for the training of young Australians. This blueprint will improve the competitiveness of our nation by building the skills of our young people so they can reach their potential, rather than removing their rights at work, as we are seeing the Howard government doing at the moment. Federal Labor will invest in schools and vocational education to offer young people better choices. We will help young people access better and more training more easily. We will create more real apprenticeships. Australians deserve a government that is serious about addressing our skills crisis and serious about investing in vocational educational and training. There is only one way to give Australians real choiceâby taking Laborâs high-skills road, not the Howard governmentâs low-wage road. It is outrageous in an area like Richmond, as I said, with over 30 per cent youth unemployment. We need to be training our young people. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI had the great pleasure of attending Korumburra Primary School only a few days ago. It is a great schoolâthis school rocks. Its award-winning choir was there on the morning to greet me at a major assembly for the whole school, as were teachers and parents. Its musical program was incredible. The choir sang I Had a Dream, led ably by Mrs Paproth. The choir came to a crescendo in I Had a Dreamâand I know the member for McEwen would remember the ABBA song I Had a Dream of 25 years ago.
âI do.

âIt was a great song, beautifully presented by these very young primary school students, and when they went into the key change you just had to grab hold of the moment and feel a part of it. Mrs Paproth was thrilled to bits. Because of a part of my background, I recognised the key change and that they went up a semi-tone. It was absolutely magnificent to be there. When I say this school rocks, they really did rock. It was just fantastic, as was the enthusiasm of the teachers.

speech.para: For what reason was I there? I was there as the federal member to praise the Reading Challenge of the Premier of Victoria and to make a few presentations. We talked about Investing in Our Schools, but then what did they do? The whole school sang I am Australian, with harmony coming from the choir and with five teachers playing guitarâit was absolutely sensational. The Minister for Small Business and Tourism, the member for McEwen, did not believe me when I said Korumburra Primary School rocks! It really does, and they are academically great achievers. Every member of one class completed the Reading Challenge set by the Premier.

However, my difficulty was that the children then asked me in front of everybody what my favourite childhood book was. My favouriteâI know every member here, joining us in this parliament this evening, will remember this one, and I thank all the members for joining us this evening as we wind up the weekâwas Little Toot. I explained to them why mine was Little Toot. Little Toot had three or four goes at getting where he was going. He got to the mountain a couple of times and fell back, and had another go and fell back, and had another go and fell back. I was explaining to the young students how important it is never to give up and to be persistent and to always keep trying. Even if you are not the best book reader, it is important to have a go at reading a book, and they did.

Of course these childrenâand I know every member in this House feels exactly the same way as I doâare our future. The teachers who teach them have a heavy responsibility for what they do. Especially the mums who are in this House tonight, and perhaps the future mums who are in this House tonight, will feel that responsibility and know the challenges that their children went through, be they health challenges or academic challenges or just growing-up challenges. So a heavy responsibility has been given to Korumburra Primary School, their principal and their teachers, and they are working through it. This government also has provided money right across Victoria for Investing in Our Schools.

It was a tremendous pleasure for me to go to Elizabeth Street Primary School and deliver some money to them. It has been a difficult school in Moe for years. They were just absolutely beside themselves to get their money. At the Nyora Primary School I was able to sit under a 100-year-old oak tree and think of the generations that have gone through the school. I was able to congratulate them on a citizenship program that they had invested in. I have already told the House about Korumburra Primary School. The other day the Minister for Education, Science and Training, Brendan Nelson, visited the Blackwood Annexe and took some Investing in Our Schools money down there. The Blackwood Annexe is absolutely sensational. So sometimes members of parliament have great days, and the great day I had was when Korumburra Primary School rocked.

talk.start.para: âWhat a delight it is to follow on from a member talking with such enthusiasm about something that happened in his electorate. I too would like to use my time this afternoon to talk about a project which, while it has not yet taken place, I have very great enthusiasm for and to which I wish to give my strongest possible support. I am talking about an application that is currently with the government, under the Community Water Grants scheme, to rejuvenate and revitalise the Murray Lagoon in Rockhampton. Visitors to Rockhampton, and indeed the residents of Rockhampton, know that the botanical gardens area of our city is an absolute jewel. It is a very special place, of which we are all very proud.

speech.para: The Rockhampton Botanical Gardens is bordered by Murray Lagoon and it is also adjacent to the Rockhampton Golf Club. The application currently before the government seeking $50,000 from the Community Water Grants scheme is a joint project between the Rockhampton Golf Club and the Central Queensland University to do a feasibility study into the harvesting and filtering of stormwater and recycled water through the wetlands and into Murray Lagoon. As I said, the botanical gardens, the golf club and the Murray Lagoon area is a real jewel in Rockhampton city; but over the last few years, because of the extremely dry conditions we have been experiencing right around the country, the wetlands, the Murray Lagoon area, has become seriously depleted of water and has deteriorated significantly.

In this once beautiful area that was an important habitat for fish, turtles, native birds and other forms of wildlifeâit was a very important ecosystemâthe water has gradually receded until it is now almost totally dry. It is really just an area covered with noxious weeds, introduced plant species and feral animals. The poor pelicans, native birds and other species are being forced into a smaller and smaller area, and it is a very sad thing to see when this is such a special and beautiful place.

The application that is before the government at the moment is a fantastic project. It is a classic win-win situation which has the support of a great number of stakeholders in Rockhampton. I have already mentioned the project partners CQU and the Rockhampton Golf Club, but it is also supported by the Environmental Protection Agency, the department of natural resources and the Rockhampton City Council, among others. The idea is to design a best-practice system to harvest and filter stormwater and treated effluent through artificial and enhanced natural wetlands.

Now we have a situation where Murray Lagoon is dry and the Rockhampton Golf Club would like to have access to a source of water to do its own irrigation. We have got a situation where stormwater and treated effluent is being pumped back into the Fitzroy River by the Rockhampton City Council. The Fitzroy River empties into the Great Barrier Reef, so anything that we can do to divert that stormwater and treated effluent is going to be helping the water quality in the Fitzroy River and also on the Great Barrier Reef. We are looking at the feasibility of diverting that water into wetlands and into Murray Lagoon. It will reduce effluent discharge into the river and supply irrigation water to the golf course and the botanical gardens, and the publicity that this fantastic project will receive from local media outletsâwho have indicated their very strong supportâwill get the message of water reuse and water conservation throughout the whole community.

There is also an opportunity for Indigenous youth to be involved through a training project in conjunction with this project. So I give this project my very strongest support. It is a fantastic example of the kind of community spirit we have in Rockhampton, where people get together to collaborate on something that will be good on so many levels and once again return Murray Lagoon to being a fantastic asset to our city. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âWe have been considering in the course of this week some of the very real challenges that confront Australia today, in the shape of terrorism and of disease in the form of avian flu. But the greatest challenge that our nation has ever faced and the greatest threat that there has been to its security and the liberties of Australians was during the Second World War, which ended 60 years ago in August. This year we have been celebrating and commemorating the end of that war.

speech.para: Tomorrow, 95 veterans and widows of veterans of the Second World War will be presented by me and General Peter Cosgrove with the World War II commemorative medals which the Commonwealth government has struck and which are being presented to approximately 250,000 veterans of that war. This ceremony will be held at Victoria Barracks in Sydney, one of the oldest military establishments in Australia. The Australian Army band, under the directorship of Major Andrea Davey, will be playing, and in addition to the 95 veterans and widows there will be another 300 family members and friends. It will be a wonderful occasion and a very fitting way to remember the sacrifice of all those whose served Australia in the Second World War and to honour those who have survived the 60 years with the presentation of the medal.

The veterans and their widows will be joined by representatives from the Rose Bay RSL, the Bondi Junction-Waverley RSL, the Paddington-Woollahra RSL and the Clovelly RSL, which are the principal returned servicemenâs organisations in my electorate. Earlier this year the federal government made funds available to the Bondi Junction-Waverly RSL and the Rose Bay RSL under the program Saluting Their Service 2005, which gave the means and the wherewithal to many community organisations to hold their own celebrationsâmostly in Augustâto commemorate the end of the Second World War.

At the ceremony tomorrow we will be presenting these medals to the veterans, many of whom are very old friends of mine. Winston Summerhayesâbetter known as Buster Summerhayesâa great doctor in the eastern suburbs of Sydney, was for many years the honorary medical adviser to the City Tattersalls Harriers in Centennial Park. Buster Summerhayes will be there and fitter, probably, than most of the younger people. He is a great athlete. My father-in-law, Tom Hughes, who is of course a former member of this parliament, will also be there. Tom served in the Air Force in the Second World War and he is still at the peak of his forensic powers as he approaches his 82nd birthday at the end of November.

It will also be a great honour for us all in Wentworth to have General Peter Cosgrove at our ceremony. He retired as Chief of the Defence Force in 2005 and is one of the most distinguished servicemen in Australia in modern times. He became a national figure following his appointment as Commander of International Forces East Timor, where he led the Australian force that ensured the safety and security of that fledging nation. He was responsible, along with the men and women who served under him, for overseeing East Timorâs transition to independence during what was a very tense and uncertain period both in East Timor and, more widely, in Indonesia.

Tomorrow, Wentworth will remember the men and women who defended Australia in the Second World War. Their example of heroism and commitment will be in the forefront of our minds, as I am sure it has been in the forefront of the minds of all Australians, especially during this year, the 60th anniversary of the end of our greatest struggleâthe end of the war when we were most at threat and the end of the war when many Australians paid the greatest sacrifice in our defence. (Time expired)

business.start.para: The DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. IR Causley) took the chair at 9.30 am.

talk.start.para: âI rise to speak on a matter concerning the MV Mawashi Al Gaseem, which was impounded in South Australia seven months ago. The Mawashi Al Gaseem is a livestock carrierâconverted from an oil tankerâthat arrived in Australia in March to pick up livestock to deliver to Saudi Arabia. While in berth, the MV Mawashi Al Gaseem was seized. A court action for nonpayment of fuel accounts was filed against its owners, and it could not leave till its debts were paid. This meant that the 69 mainly Filipino crew and captain were stranded, not having received any wages, and they remained unpaid for up to six months whilst the ship was held. Many of the crew were in a desperate plight, as they were the breadwinners for their extended families living in poverty back home in the Philippines, to whom they normally sent most of their wages. Many others connected by family ties were also depending on their help to pay bills for food, medicines and the education of their children.

speech.para: Imagine what could have been going through the minds of crewmen stranded in a strange place, with no money and uncertain of the future. Some of the crew did not even have enough money to telephone their families back home in the Philippines. But thank God for the generous, supportive Filipino community in South Australia. Their generosity meant that the crew who stayed on were looked after whilst in Adelaide. The captain and his crew were strongly supported by the Apostle Ship of the Sea, the MUA and the ITF, who had campaigned against these âships of shameââflags of convenience vessels, whose owners treat employees like disposable garbage. The Filipino community in South Australia, the local parish church and the broader Catholic community together provided material and moral support to all the crew. Religious services were held aboard the vessel, barbecues were held on shore to raise money for the crew, and donations were collected. Many of the crew were invited into the homes of the local Filipino community. Incidentally, this was drawn to my attention by the local mayor, John Trainer, who has close ties to the leaders of the community.

The courage, hope and optimism of people in such adverse conditions should be recognised and celebrated. The moral leadership of Roman Alcantara Jr, the captain of Mawashi Al Gasseem, kept his crew focused despite the difficult circumstances that they were in. Leadership such as this, displayed when things are at their worst, should be acknowledged. So should the involvement and the help of the strong local Filipino community that we have in South Australia. The Filipino community responded to the needs of those on board the ship and tried to alleviate their plight. Month after month, the crew waited to be paid, dreading going home empty-handed to those who depended on them under these dreadful circumstances. Even the most level-headed people would be exasperated. One or two of the crew members were nearly suicidal. But the captain ensured that the Filipino crew did not lose their cool.

I will have the pleasure this Saturday in Adelaide of attending a ceremony organised by the Filipino community under the guidance of journalist Norma Hennessy and Dr Dante Juanta, OAM, to express appreciation for and pay tribute to the shipâs master, Captain Roman Alcantara Jr, and to acknowledge the efforts of the many local Filipino and Australian families who helped the crew with care and compassion. They understood this question: if we are not on this planet to help each other, then what are we here for?

talker.name: Gambaro, Teresa, MP
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence
talker.name: Ms GAMBARO

talk.start.para: âOn Friday 28 October, I had great pleasure in joining Operation Smile for their gala charity ball. Operation Smile is a not-for-profit volunteer medical services organisation providing reconstructive surgery and related health care to children and young adults in developing countries. To say it was one of the most moving experiences of my life would be an understatement. I want to place on the record my great thanks to a constituent of mine, Dr Richard Lewandowski, and his wonderful medical team of miracle workers. Some of the things they do are just amazing. It has been 12 months since they sent a 16-strong Australian team out of Brisbane for their first mission to Deesa, India. Of the 360 patients who were screened on that mission, 165 received surgery. In January in 2006 a representative team of surgeons, nurses and other medical professionals will fly back to Deesa to give more children suffering from cleft lips and palates the chance of a new life. They have a profound effect on these childrenâs lives.

speech.para: I want to recount one particular story that was told, of 25-year-old Dipakkumar Patel and his father, who come from Deesa in that north-west area of India. They arrived on 11 September this year. Dipakkumar was born with a condition which is called plexiform neurofibroma, which really equates to the old term that we know as the âelephant manâ type syndrome. He came to Brisbane. The team operated over a period of about 10 hours. Not only has he been given a new face, which is just extraordinaryâI wish I could show you some of the photos; the before and after shots are just incredibleâbut he has a new opportunity to teach children in India. He is a trained teacher. He was unable to teach because of his massive deformities. It was thought that he would frighten the children. He is now able to go back to India and teach in his village. It has had a profound effect.

Things like cleft palates are nothing to us in Western societies. They can be dealt with very quickly. But in a place like India or Vietnam, where there is no medical attention or help when children are born, it just destroys their lives. They cover their faces; they do not want to be seen. As soon as these operations are performed they have a new lease on lifeâthey are willing to look in the mirror again and to take part in life, in simple things like getting married. They are now able to get married, because they no longer have a deformity. I would like to place on record the wonderful work that Dr Lewandowski and his team at Operation Smile do. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThis morning I want to give another example from my electorate of the blatant discrimination of the Howard government against same-sex couples. Twenty years ago my constituent Jiro Takamisawa met and fell in love with Jack George, a war veteran. For two decades Jiro and Jack lived together and shared their lives. Jiro became an Australian citizen and lived in a caring relationship with Jack for over 20 years. Some years ago Jackâs health deteriorated due to his war service, and Jiro reduced his hours of work to provide full-time care for his partner. In October last year Jack passed away surrounded by his friends, his family and his loving partner, Jiro.

speech.para: In December, knowing that he would not be eligible but to make a point, Jiro applied to the Department of Veteransâ Affairs for a war widows pension. To his amazement, on 20 January 2005 he received a letter from the Department of Veteransâ Affairs awarding him a pension and enclosing a veterans gold card. That same afternoon he rang the department to point out to them that he thought perhaps they had made an error. They had addressed the letter to Ms Takamisawa, and he wanted to be addressed in the future as Mr Takamisawa. He told them that he was a man and perhaps they had made a mistake. He said there was dead silence at the end of the phone and the next day a courier arrived with a letter taking back his gold card and taking away his pension.

On that same day he came to my office to discuss with me this discrimination. Jiro lodged an appeal to the Veterans Review Board, which was heard on 10 August. The boardâs decision states very clearly that but for his gender Jiro would have been eligible for a war widows pension and all of the associated benefits. Every other criterion was met in this case.

Many months ago, in January, I wrote to the Minister for Veteransâ Affairs to ask her how long her department would continue to discriminate against same-sex couples. I wrote again in April, but I am still waiting for a reply. That is better than the Attorney-General, who wrote to me saying, âThe government condemns discrimination in all its forms, including discrimination on the basis of sexuality.â In the same letter he said, âThe government does not consider that every distinction on the basis of sexual preference is illegitimate.â I am perplexed that someone who is the first law officer of this country can make such an illogical argument. I believe this sort of discrimination is always illegitimate. There is no consistency in the way same-sex relationships are recognised. Jiro was awarded a part carers pension from Centrelink while he cared for his partner. He was granted Australian citizenship on the basis of their relationshipâboth measures that Labor introduced. The only legislation that this government has introduced under which Jiro would be treated as a spouse is the terrorism legislation. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âIn recent weeks I have had the pleasure of visiting year 3 students of the Bundaberg South State School, who took out the state category for lower primary grades in the national Hands on for Habitat awards. These students worked in small groups to learn about mammals such as the humpback whale, the dusky hopping mouse and the ghost bat and used recycled materials to make striking collages of these various species in their native habitats. Their artwork was judged the best of all the lower primary grades in Queensland, and the school and the entire Bundaberg community is rightly proud of their achievement.

speech.para: To give you some idea of how keen the competition was, there were almost 4,000 children across Australia who submitted 230 class entries to this yearâs competition. Only 18 schools were chosen as winners, so the children at the Bundaberg South State School have done extraordinarily well to take out the Queensland lower primary category. As just reward for their efforts, each school received a $200 voucher to buy native plants for their school grounds so that students can have a tangible and ever-present resource to help them learn about Australiaâs unique wildlife and flora. The school also received a framed National Threatened Species Day poster featuring the grade 3âs artwork. I inspected the work on display in the school library. It was a stunning relief of the ghost bat; the children did extraordinarily well.

Hinkler students have a remarkable track record in the Hands on for Habitat awards. Last year, Boyne Island State Schoolâs Adam Romagnolo had his artwork judged in the National Threatened Species Day sticker series, and his picture of a loggerhead turtle was chosen as the winner. His picture was selected from more than 4,300 entries because of its beauty and creativity, and I know that the Gladstone community was very proud of having one of their local students win such a national competition. Hands on for Habitat awards are important and practical tools for teaching young people how to care for our environment. In a fun and engaging way they emphasise Australiaâs threatened species and flora and what we can do to preserve these plants and animals.

talk.start.para: âToday I would like to bring to the attention of the House a matter of great concern, one that I think should concern members on both sides of this parliament. I believe that this issue which I am going to raise in the House has the potential to impact on all members. Prior to the passage of the Telstra legislation, the legislation that gave Telstra the green light for full privatisation, I was being contacted by Telstra Country Wide on a very regular basis to organise appointments. They always wanted to talk to me about issues. But, unfortunately, since they have had the green light I have noticed a change in the way they relate to me.

speech.para: I asked the area general manager of Newcastle and Lake Macquarie Telstra Country Wide to meet and speak with residents of Redhead, one of the communities within Shortland electorate but, unfortunately, he has refused to do so. The residents are very worried about a Telstra tower being erected in their area, and I thought that the best way to resolve the issue was for him to come along to talk to the residents and see whether we could develop a compromise so that there would be a win-win solution rather than what is happening nowâan enormous amount of community division and concern.

I am shocked and horrified that the Telstra area general manager would arrogantly refuse to meet with the residents. It seems to me that this is an indication of things to come, and that should worry all of us. I am so disgusted by his refusal to meet with the residents that, rather than sitting down, having a quiet meeting, talking to the residents and looking at alternatives, I have now organised a public meeting with the residents of Redhead for six oâclock on Friday on the site where they are going to erect the tower. Thankfully, one of the councillors from Lake Macquarie Council is coming along with me to the meeting. Late Macquarie Council will be looking at this matter on Monday night, and I am sure they will adopt a different approach from the approach that has been adopted by Telstra Country Wide. This is a very environmentally significant piece of land. They want to erect this tower right on the bluff at Redhead. Arrogance of this kind is not good enough.

If Telstra refuses to meet with the residents, I certainly will not refuse. I intend to ensure that their voices are heard and that their concerns are listened to. Arrogance breeds contempt, and that is what Telstra is showing for the people of Redhead. It is not good enough. I want the same sorts of meeting procedures with Telstra that it was offering before it was given the green light for full privatisation. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI would like to advise the House that this morning the Australian Export Awards finalists were announced in the Great Hall. I would further like to advise the House that one of those finalists is with us in the gallery this morningâMr Kimbo Kim. It is interesting that Mr Kim, who is Korean, has become a finalist in Australiaâs export awards. It is the way things are going in the global village that we live in today, and the member for McPherson, who is in the chamber, will understand when I explain Mr Kimâs background.

speech.para: Mr Kim is the Managing Director and Executive Producer of Base Camp, a company located in Melbourne, and he produces particularly fine television commercials. The member for McPherson, who is familiar with the movie industry on the Gold Coast, will know just how good our Australian people are in the technicalities of producing video and film material. Mr Kim has brought his business to Australia. He uses the technical people that we have in Australia because they are as good as anyone else in the world. But he also comes to Australia because our climate, our pollution-free atmosphere, our scenery and our geography are as good as any in the world. Mr Kim is able to do international commercials right here in Australia. That generates export dollars for our country.

Mr Kim, we welcome you to Australia. We thank you for bringing your expertise to our country, for using our people and for generating dollars for our country. I guess one or two dollars might go into your pocket as well, but that is what it is about and we do not mind that at all. We congratulate you on the award that you have received today, and we hope that you will be a winner when the winners are announced in Sydney in the next few weeks. Well done.

talk.start.para: âWith so much talk of the governmentâs proposed sedition laws and the clear fear out there among activists that basic freedoms will be curtailed, I thought it was important today to quietly acknowledge the contribution that one group of activists has made to the future of this country. A group of Australians has been working for the last seven years on a project that reached an important milestone a few weeks ago when the Convention on Cultural Diversity was finally passed by UNESCO in Paris on 20 October.

speech.para: The convention reaffirms that countries have the sovereign right to protect and promote diversity of cultural expression on their territory. Most of UNESCOâs members saw the resolution as an important tool for protecting local languages, arts and culture, particularly in a world where free trade pressures aim to extinguish that right. Not so Australia. When the voting finally went down, with 154 countries present, the vote was won 148 to two, with the US and Israel opposing. And in this near unanimous result Australia went missing, being one of only four countries, along with Liberia, Honduras and Nicaragua, to abstain from voting. While many countries drew attention to inconsistencies in the convention, as Australia did, they still managed to vote in favour of it. They did so because they supported the broad principles and realised the importance of showing support for artistic and cultural values.

The convention came about because of the work of many people around the world over several years. The International Network for Cultural Diversity was formed in 2000 to represent artists and non-government cultural organisations from about 70 countries. It included Dr Richard Letts from the Music Council of Australia. A parallel network of cultural ministers was also formed, called the International Network on Cultural Policy. Fifty-three countries were members. Australia was not.

A third organisation, the International Coalition for Cultural Diversity, was formed following an inaugural international meeting of peak cultural industry bodies in Montreal in 2001âa meeting I was fortunate to attend in my then capacity as CEO of the Association of Independent Record Labels. The Australian version of that organisation was formed immediately following that meeting and has worked tirelessly since then to ensure that Australia retains the right to determine its own cultural policies. It took the fight to our government here. While the international movement did not have the support of the Australian government, it did have the support of the Australian creative industries.

Organisations to be acknowledged include the Media Entertainment and Arts Alliance, the Australian Writers Guild, the Arts Law Centre, the Australian Society of Authors, the National Association for the Visual Arts, the Australian Book Publishers Association, the Music Council of Australia, the Australian Screen Directors Association, the Screen Producers Association of Australia, Create Australia and the Australian Performing Rights Associationâan extraordinary group of associations representing our best and brightest creative minds. I congratulate them on the work that they have done in working with their international colleagues to bring this convention into existence. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: McPherson Electorate: Work for the Dole

talk.start.para: âRecently I had the opportunity of inspecting the recently painted frog mural along the Pacific Highway in my electorate, which was painted by Work for the Dole participants. The frog mural is the latest addition to a number of themes along the only road in the world where the walls have been painted to such a large extent. Not only do we have a colourful mural brightening up the landscape but the Work for the Dole activity has provided some valuable research into frogs.

speech.para: Frogs are a gauge of environment health, and the participants involved in this project were keen to improve the conservation status and long-term survival of local frog species through visual promotion and the protection of frog habitats. It was a real concern to the participants that during the project the sightings of frogs were very rare and the ones that were found were deformed. The deformities have been attributed to the pesticides used in gardens. I urge all Australians today to use some friendly pesticides in their gardens when feeding their lawns or their plants or spraying for weeds. Pouring boiling water over weeds is an environmentally friendly way to get rid of weeds. Large amounts of saltâa by-product of pesticidesâwere also found.

The Work for the Dole participants also learnt about graphic and web design. They have produced and developed a CD, booklet and web site. The educational materials, along with the coloured charts they have produced that help identify the disease, show that it is possible to raise disease- and pesticide-free frogs. The kit also includes a number of frog sounds that help to identify different species of frogs.

The Work for the Dole project has now started our whole community talking and thinking about frogs and protecting them. Griffith University students have just been given a research grant to undertake further research and develop a system or model for the investigation into frog populations on the Gold Coast. The decline and extinction of frog species has also been attributed to a virus.

I would like to congratulate all those who were involved in the Work for the Dole project, entitled Frogscaping and Bioprospecting. The project itself has been recognised as a highly commended Work for the Dole project in the recent Prime Ministerâs Work for the Dole Achievement Awards. I would like to offer my congratulations to all those involved in the project, including the community work coordinator; the Queensland Vocational Training College, which was the sponsor organisation; and Mothers against Drugs, which undertook the project in my electorate of McPherson. It was well represented. The 32 participants have got jobs out of this Work for the Dole project, but we have also been able to produce some very valuable research on frog populations on the Gold Coast.

subdebateinfo.title: Cunningham Electorate: Strategic Community Assistance to Refugee Families

talk.start.para: âLast Saturday I had the great pleasure of launching an initiative of some very dedicated local people aimed at providing practical assistance to newly settled refugees in our area from the African countries. This group has been named SCARF, which stands for Strategic Community Assistance to Refugee Families, and was established in March this year. Firstly, I would like to extend my sincere congratulations to Sharyn McKenzie, Jane Coburn and their team of volunteers. These local people saw another group in the community facing real problems and decided to try and find a solution, a way in which local people could help each other.

speech.para: SCARF is offering mentoring programs where local families support newly settled refugee families in the challenges of navigating a new society which is unfamiliar and where another language is spoken. These mentors familiarise the adults with such important processes as simply doing the shopping, dealing with Centrelink and schools, looking for employment or training, and various daily activities that can be a bit bewildering if you are in an unfamiliar society. I also commend SCARF for the focus they have put on providing assistance to the children of these families. Local volunteers run homework help sessions for high-school students and home tutoring for primary school students.

I made the point at the official launch on Saturday that communities are strengthened when we take action to make sure that all people can find a role and a purpose in their community. It is not enough to simply be tolerant and inclusive. We also need to take meaningful, practical action to ensure that people are not marginalised or denied full and active participation in workplaces, schools, education courses and of course the broader community. Building links through families is one of the oldest and most effective ways of achieving this highly desired result.

Local volunteers have indicated to me that the families being settled into our area from African nations require a quite unprecedented level of support, as they are a very disparate group who may be arriving from the same continent but have originated from different countries with often very different languages, cultural backgrounds and life experiences from each other, let alone from the new community into which they settle. This makes it difficult to establish the standard group links that former waves of refugees were able to achieve with each other, as they shared a common language and culture.

The nature of this challenge means the governmentâs settlement programs that are modelled on a one-size-fits-all approach, which may have been appropriate in the past, regularly fail to achieve the intended outcomes with such groups. In particular, careful, considerate assessment on arrival of literacy levels and problems needs to be done for many of the children. They have had very limited, if any, schooling experience, and the problems of beginning a new school with English as a second language are exacerbated by this. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Gilmore Electorate: Yurana Cancer Kids Holiday Homes

talk.start.para: âThere is only one thing more heart-rending than the vibrancy of youth being stolen by deathâthat is, knowing beforehand that it is going to happen. You stand and wait for the inevitable moment, hoping that somehow there will be a salvation, but that never comes. âYuranaâ is an Aboriginal word for âlovingâ, and in Ulladulla we have given this name to a series of houses that have been set aside to be used as holiday homes for kids with a terminal illness. Yuranaâs first home was opened in July 1988 by 10-year-old Kate Critchlow, herself a victim of cancer. Kate died shortly after, in September, knowing that the houseâlater known as Kateâs House, in celebration of her lifeâwould provide many children and their families with a holiday which would be a welcome relief away from the rigorous rounds of hospital routines and treatments.

speech.para: Since then, the management committee has continued fundraising and Yurana now has a Lukeâs House in Burrill Lake plus two more in Ulladulla, known as Laird House and Amberâs House. This fundraising is a continuing process as the committee works hard to give more and more kids and their families a final chance at happiness in their lives. However, for some unknown reason, they have had difficulties filling the vacancies. You would have thought that people would have been anxious to take advantage of the opportunity offered, at no cost to the family, but the opposite is occurring. I do not know whether there has not been enough publicity and therefore people do not know enough about Yurana and their four houses, but I do know that these homes are there to be used. All that is required is a referral from a doctor. Ulladulla is a beautiful setting, and I am quite proud of the fact that it is in my electorate. I would recommend the location to anyone contemplating a holiday on the South Coast.

What I would like to do is draw membersâ attention to the Yurana Cancer Kidâs Holiday Homes in the hope that they would promote the facilities throughout their electorates so that children with a terminal illness can enjoy the few days that have been given to them. I should add that Yurana is not limited to children with cancer but is open to any child with a terminal illness.

Yurana is but one of many similar services available for children with cancer, and I am truly grateful that there are so many in our country wanting to bring a little sunshine into otherwise darkened lives. I suppose I am more surprised than disappointed that these units cannot be filled, and I would genuinely like to know why. However, I would like to take this opportunity to pay homage to the many individuals who work for kids with cancer, because it takes a special kind of person, with a big heart, to give a little to these children and their families. The invisible, non-publicity seeking people who run Yurana are to my mind unique, and I would love very much to see their efforts being rewarded with more children and their families coming to Ulladulla and enjoying a holiday together. Let us work to make some of their wishes come true. Mr Maurie Bates, vice president, and his committee would love to hear from members and families in order to offer those children who are terminally ill a chance to be with their families in a holiday setting that offers so much.

subdebateinfo.title: Shortland Electorate: Swansea Meals on Wheels

talk.start.para: âIn the time that remains for membersâ three-minute statements, I would like to acknowledge the fine work of Swansea Meals on Wheels. On 31 August this year I was able to go on the rounds with the volunteer workers at Swansea Meals on Wheels and deliver meals to elderly people in the area. I saw the dedication of the workers and the value of their visits to the homes of the people that they delivered the meals to. Meals on Wheels is a fine organisation, and I would particularly like to pay credit to those who work at Swansea Meals on Wheels.
(Hon. IR Causley)âOrder! In accordance with sessional order 193 the time for membersâ statements has concluded.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 2 November, on motion by Mr Entsch:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: upon which Mr Martin Ferguson moved by way of amendment:

motion.para: That all words after âThatâ be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
âwhilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House:

item.para: calls on the Government to introduce energy efficiency to all sectors of the community, including transport, and housing, as well as business;
condemns the Government for failing to support the alternative fuel and renewable energy industries; and

condemns the Government for not adopting the bipartisan recommendations put forward by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Heritage in its report on Sustainable Citiesâ.

talk.start.para: âI rise to speak on the Energy Efficiency Opportunities Bill 2005 and to support the amendment moved by the member for Batman, Laborâs shadow minister. On this side of the House we do broadly support the thrust of this legislation, but I admit to being distinctly lukewarm. This bill establishes a mandatory regime for assessing the energy efficiency opportunities for businesses which are very large energy users. It also requires the public reporting of the energy efficiency assessments. However, it does not mandate implementing those assessments to actually effect those savings.

speech.para: The businesses to be covered by this regime are the biggest energy users in our country. The regime covers roughly 250 of the largest businesses, mainly in the mining, commercial, petroleum and chemicals, food and beverage, metals, and transport industries. It is estimated that the 250 businesses to be included in this scheme use around 60 per cent of all the energy used by business in Australia. As energy is not a fixed overhead but a controllable cost, saving energy can save money. It is estimated that saving 10 per cent of energy will provide a five per cent increase in profit and in most cases will lead to more production capacity. That is good for the economy and good for the creation of jobs.

While the businesses in question are not actually required to implement any of these efficiencies, it is hoped that the public reporting mechanism will help bring about a culture of awareness and preparedness to do that. While we support the bill, Labor believe there is a great deal more that could be done by this government to help reconcile our need for energy and our need to protect our environment and natural resources.

Australia, unfortunately, has not kept pace with the rest of the world in improving energy efficiency, with previous attempts to include businesses in voluntary efficiency programs having very little take-up. It is good to see, then, that this bill does introduce at least a mandatory public reporting regime. I do hope businesses take up the energy efficiency opportunities they identify and thereby contribute to reducing the greenhouse emissions associated with energy use. But clearly the government could be doing more. With rapidly increasing energy costs and the clear threat posed by climate change, it goes without saying that we need to be conserving our resources and moving to cleaner energy sources and technologies.

In July the Greenpeace ship Rainbow Warrior sailed into Newcastle harbour in my electorate to attempt to stop the export of coal. When it did so, it actually did two things: it drew much-needed attention to the appalling lack of security that the Howard government provides at our ports and it highlighted the need for us to think very seriously about the technologies we are going to be using in the future to generate our power. It was not an accident that Rainbow Warrior ended up in Newcastle harbour. My electorate of Newcastle is built on coal. The port itself is at the mouth of what now is called the Hunter River but was once called Coal River. Newcastle is the largest and most efficient coal-exporting port in Australia and coal is, and for many years will continue to be, an important source of energy for Australia as well as a valuable export. The dilemma we face is that coal undoubtedly causes greenhouse emissions, which contribute to climate change, yet the coal chain is one of our great job creators and economic contributors.

Last night the Hunter Valley Research Foundation released the results of a survey which showed that 54 per cent of people in the Hunter believe that the benefits of coal continue to outweigh the negative effects of the coal industry. Newcastle is a classic example of the delicate balance we need to strike between preserving our environment and preserving jobs. Fortunately, CSIRO Energy Technology headquarters is located appropriately at the CSIRO Energy Transformed flagship centre in Newcastle. The energy centreâs work is focused on improving the efficiency of coal technologies and finding ways to reduce the environmental impacts. It is looking at technologies that will dramatically reduce greenhouse gas emissions and techniques to clean carbon from emissions and store it safely.

Its research also supports the use of our coal in advanced low-emission power generation and in assisting existing power stations to optimise their processes. It is also researching the sequestration of CO gases in conjunction with the CRC for Coal in Sustainable Development. It works with the Centre for Low Emission Technology on coal gasification and the gas cleaning, processing and separation technologies necessary to capture CO from advanced coal based power stations.

The process of gasification can be taken a step further in integrated gasification combined cycle systems, which take the clean gas and burn it in a conventional gas turbine to produce electrical energy. The hot exhaust gas is recovered then and used to boil water, creating steam for a turbine, which also produces electrical energy. This process has a higher thermal efficiency than conventional power plants, meaning less coal is actually consumed to produce the same amount of energy, with the associated lowering of CO emissions. The CSIRO certainly is leading the way in finding ways to make our use of coal more efficient and clean.

Another program that the CSIRO looks at is ways to separate carbon dioxide from flue gases and pump it in liquid form into stable rock formations underground, a technique which has already been used very successfully in Scandinavian countries. By continuing to invest in research to clean up coal power production, the CSIRO does believe that it could actually have the technology available within 10 years to affordably cut the Hunterâs greenhouse gas emissions from power generation to almost zero. That is pretty exciting. It is also vital for the coal industry and our environment. I commend the CSIRO and Dr John Wright, particularly, for leading the way.

I also commend it for putting its research into practice at its CSIRO Energy Technology headquarters in my electorate. The building itself implements and showcases some of the energy efficiency opportunities that we could expect that businesses would identify and, hopefully, implement when this legislation comes into force. I would recommend to everybody that they visit the CSIRO energy flagship headquarters in Newcastle. It is an exciting building. The devices used and the systems used to save energy are a revelation and certainly, I hope, inspire anyone who goes there.

It is not only the CSIRO which is showing the way on energy efficiency and greenhouse reduction in Newcastle. I would also like to draw attention to and congratulate Newcastle City Council. It is very much enhancing our cityâs reputation as a world leader in local environmental sustainability initiatives. Between 1995 and 2000 Newcastle City Council cut its annual electricity bill from $1 million down to $650,000 through a program of retro-fitting buildings and facilities to be more energy efficient. The councilâs program paid for itself in two years and actually created extra jobs along the way. In partnership with EnergyAustralia and Hunter Water, about 6,000 homes in the region have also been fitted with energy- and water-saving devices in the past 12 months.

Newcastle City Council is also to be congratulated for winning a national local government award this year for its Greenhouse Action in Newcastle Plan. This plan set out a series of 88 actions for implementation across all sectors of the community between 2001 and 2008. Its focus includes electricity, natural gas, transport, street lighting, waste, vegetation and water. The action is aimed not only at saving businesses and families money but also at producing a 25 per cent reduction in greenhouse gas emissions below what would be projected if we were to do nothing.

Under that program the council plans to build on its own energy efficiency initiatives by targeting a further 30 per cent reduction in its own emissions below 1995 levels. These targets will be audited with what is believed to be the worldâs first online âclimate-camâ to gauge the amount of greenhouse gases produced each month in Newcastle. Actually, we are the only city that I know in Australia that can give you a monthly measure of our emissions. It is an ambitious plan. It is innovative. It is a plan that Newcastle City Council has sold all around Australia and is now exporting. It fully deserves a national local government award. I congratulate Newcastle City Council and look forward to being with it at its presentation next week.

I also note that Newcastle has put in a bid to be one of the four solar cities to be announced early next year. If successful, I know it will pave the way for around 40 new projects in our region, including the installation of solar panels and further refitting of offices, schools and homes with energy efficient lights and airconditioning. With such a strong track record in the promotion of energy efficiency programs, Newcastle is clearly well placed to be one of the solar cities. I have supported Newcastleâs bid in the past, and I take this opportunity to wholeheartedly do so again.

Newcastle is doing its part at the local level. However, the federal government does not seem to be showing the same kind of commitment. The Solar Cities scheme is welcome, but it is nowhere near enough. Under that program, four cities across the nation will be required to split $75 million over seven years. That simply is not the comprehensive response to greenhouse gases and dangerous climate change that is required.

For starters, the government, we would always assert, should have agreedâand still could agreeâto sign the Kyoto treaty. Australia and the United States are the only developed nations not to have signed the treaty. Coming from a coal-producing area, I know that unless we start participating in the energy credit trading schemes then certainly one day people will point to us and require us to do far more than the protocol requires. One hundred and fifty-six other nations think this is how we should move forward to combat climate change. It seems that only our Prime Minister and President Bush believe it is a bad idea to sign on to a rigorous protocol developed over many years and supported by most international scientific experts.

Australiaâs isolation from the Kyoto treaty also isolates us from the economic opportunities that arise from the international emissions trading scheme. As Australia is on track to meet our Kyoto target of 108 per cent of 1990 emissions by 2012 anyway, it simply does not make sense to miss out on the benefits that also come with signing the protocol. The government should reverse its decision and sign the Kyoto protocol.

Another area in which the Howard government has been letting Australia down is in the management of research and development in this country. It is interesting that we are having a productivity debate about low labour costs when, really, the debate should be about investment in knowledge. Only yesterday, it was reported that the CSIRO is planning to cut back its research into renewable energy and in various other research areas. That is a disappointment to all of us. I gave the CSIRO a big wrap earlier for its excellent research into clean coal and energy efficiency technologiesâand it deserves itâbut we also need a balance between investing in those coal based technologies and investing in energy efficient and renewable technologies. In fact, why would we be cutting back research in any area of sustainability and energy efficiency? I cannot understand that at all.

Innovation skills and technology are the future for Australia. The Howard government does not seem to want to commit to that. It thinks our competitive advantage is something called Work Choices and the slashing of labour costs, wages and conditions. The Howard government seems to think you establish an advantage by treating people as simply an economic input and a commodity cost. That is never the case in this country. Perhaps mismanaging our premier research institution completely undercuts our advantage. I think it is time for a new look at Australiaâs future prosperity and productivity.

The government should also be condemned for not adopting any of the bipartisan recommendations of the recent House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Heritage report entitled Sustainable cities, which shows how serious the problems are that are afflicting our urban environments after nine years under this government. The report shows that Australiaâs cities have problems that are crying out for a national solution and that national leadership is sorely needed to make Australiaâs cities healthier and better places in which to live.

The committeeâs recommendation for an Australian sustainability charter which would set national targets for environmental health, including water, energy and transport, would be a big step in the right direction, as would the recommended independent sustainability commission, which would monitor the performance of government against these targets. This is an important report, with sensible bipartisan recommendations that a government that was serious about the future of this country would have seriously considered adopting.

Recently, the idea of developing a nuclear power industry in Australia was floated again by some who see the nuclear industry as the answer to our energy needs. I do not think any of us would deny that it is an exciting area of science. However, I do not believeâalong with 63 per cent of those surveyed by the Hunter Valley Research Foundationâthat at this stage nuclear power is a viable alternative to coal. This was announced last night in my electorate in the Hunter region. The production of nuclear power is not a greenhouse-free endeavour. You need to mine, transport and enrich the uranium, and then you need to decommission the plant at the end of its life. All of this involves the burning of fossil fuels and the creation of greenhouse gases.

Then there is the question of where to store nuclear waste, and the vexed issue of transporting this waste around our nation. We have seen the government ram through legislation this week to impose a nuclear waste dump on the Northern Territory. This is despite Territorians not wanting it, despite Territory laws that ban or regulate nuclear waste dumps and despite environmental protection, heritage and native title laws. This is just for the waste from one small research reactor. We do not know how much waste a full-scale nuclear energy industry operating in Australia would produce, nor do we know what we would do with that waste. In the United Kingdom, reprocessed waste has been sitting in cooling ponds for 50 years, and they still do not know what to do with it.

What we do know from the passage of this legislation yesterday is that the Howard government is quite prepared to dump nuclear waste wherever it wants, without consultation. What we do not know is whether a nuclear energy industry would be viable in Australia. To begin, we would have to import practically all of our expertise from overseas. We currently have world-leading scientists working on renewable and clean coal energy in Australia, but we do not have the same cohort working on nuclear energy. According to the CSIRO, serious consideration would have to be given to how we would train and develop nuclear researchers in this country. Secondly, we do not know if a nuclear industry is economically viable in this country. We know that the UKâs privatised nuclear energy producer had to be bailed out to the tune of Â£410 million in 2001.

Nuclear generation has enormous capital start-up costs as well as the enormous decommissioning costs at the end of a nuclear plantâs life span, which are often not factored into those initial cost per unit estimates. Few nations in Western Europe or the US currently plan to build new nuclear plants. The US has not built a new nuclear power station since the 1970s, while the plant under construction in Finland will be the first built in Western Europe for 15 years. Meanwhile, nations such as Sweden, Germany and Belgium are all decommissioning their existing plants. So we should not assume that just because we have uranium in the ground we should necessarily have a nuclear power industry or that we should assist it globally. If we did start up a nuclear industry, we would have to shovel the uranium out of the ground at an ever-increasing rate, with the associated environmental and cultural problems that would arise from that.

Uranium mining is a dangerous business, and this is why the Labor Party maintains as its policy a commitment to only regulated uranium mining in Australia. The Senate Standing Committee on the Environment, Communications, Information Technology and the Arts found in 2003 that âuranium mining presents unique hazards and risks to both human health and the environmentâ. A recent parliamentary committee report found that âuranium mining operations were a hazard to human healthâ, and since then an incident at the Ranger mine saw contaminated water connected to potable water. This led to workers drinking and washing in water containing contaminants at 400 times the safe drinking level.

We need to ensure safety in mining operations and that we are sensitive to the land and its traditional owners. Most of Australiaâs uranium resources are located in areas of cultural, traditional significance to Aboriginal people. In August the Howard government unilaterally announced that, when it came to another uranium mine in the Northern Territory, it was open for business. In passing its radioactive waste dumping legislation this week, it ignored the wishes of the Central Land Council, which pointed out that the traditional owners of two of the three proposed dump sites opposed a nuclear waste dump on or near their traditional land.

So nuclear power, I believe, is not the answer to our energy needs. We have world-leading research being undertaken by the CSIRO and others into establishing a viable, sustainable clean coal industry. We have action by Newcastle City Council and other local organisations at that level all working to reduce energy use. And now we have this bill, to encourage businesses to take up energy efficiency opportunities. This is welcome, but there is certainly much more that the Howard government could do.
