It could properly manage CSIRO to allow it to properly invest in a full range of environmental and energy research, including the key area of renewable energy. It could sign the Kyoto protocol to lock Australia into the international agreement on reducing greenhouse gas, and it certainly could respond to the recommendations of the Sustainable cities report. It could also stop riding roughshod over the states and territories on uranium mining and the storage of nuclear waste.

While we know the government should be doing much, much more, Labor looks forward to seeing the provisions of this bill in operation and to seeing how many Australian businesses take up the opportunity and the challenge to increase their energy efficiency for the sake of the health of the people of this nation and of our nation itself.

talk.start.para: âThe Energy Efficiency Opportunities Bill 2005 establishes an energy efficiency opportunities program under which corporations that are large energy users are required to assess the potential to improve their energy efficiency and report publicly on that assessment. According to Australian Bureau of Statistics data, around 250 companies will be covered by this measure. These 250 companies account for approximately 80 per cent of all energy used by business in Australia. In turn, overall business energy consumption represents 80 per cent of the total amount of energy used in the country as a whole. Targeting these large energy users in this way can potentially yield a very significant drop in our national energy consumption.

speech.para: This is a good initiative, but I am concerned that it does not go far enough. It comes from a government that has not shown itself to be serious about achieving greater energy efficiency and developing greater energy diversity in this country. This initiative, which requires large energy users to assess their energy use and look for ways to improve efficiency, aims to bring the resources and expertise of the private sector into the national effort that is needed to reduce our use of energy, particularly energy generated from non-renewable sources.

I believe that it would be well understood that the private sectorâs participation does have the potential to bring additional resources, including extra capital investment, as well as additional expertise, including innovations in management, that can be directed towards the goal of greater energy efficiency. However, I also believe that it would be generally agreed that the private sector often needs direction. Indeed, often legislation is needed to force them to act in what might be considered the national interest, particularly in matters concerning the environment and energy efficiency.

Even when the end result may be cost savings, there may be reluctance on the part of businesses to make changes to how they do things and to commit to the initial outlay of money that is often needed to install new equipment or otherwise put changes into effect. It is also fair to say that business often has a short-term view of its goals and lacks the motivation to change if the pay-off is not immediate. In those circumstances, it is up to government to set the agenda and encourage the private sector through a mix of incentives and regulation to be mindful of their role in achieving outcomes determined to be in the national interest.

This is where I see a great weakness in this particular legislation. While large corporations will be required to make assessments of the potential to improve their energy efficiency, they are not bound by this bill to actually implement any measures in their assessments. We know that from the governmentâs energy white paper. On 15 June 2004 the Prime Minister released a national energy white paper. The paper stated:

quote.para: These assessments will be undertaken consistent with an improved Australian standard and will be designed to identify energy efficiency investments with a payback of four years or less. Firms will be required to report publicly on the outcomes of the assessment, and will be free to make decisions on investments identified via their normal business processes.

speech.para: I would argue that, if we are to ask our largest corporations to assess the opportunities that they may have, then the very least we should expect is that those recommendations be implemented rather than left up to the individual corporations to decide on their implementation.

I understand from the Parliamentary Libraryâs Bills Digest that that is in contrast to the Victorian legislation. Under that regime, certain businesses that operate under the Environmental Protection Agency statutory approvals must examine and implement measures to improve energy efficiency and reduce greenhouse gas emissions. As a result of the Victorian government showing some leadership in this area, it is anticipated that the first three years of the program will yield greenhouse gas emission reductions of approximately 1.15 million tonnes of carbon dioxide annually. It is not clear to me why the federal government has stopped short of requiring implementation. That is one way in which this bill could be improved.

Another area which I believe has been neglected by this billâperhaps it is something that could be addressed very simply through a change in government policyâis the role of the government itself in practising and promoting energy efficiency. The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Heritage, in its excellent report Sustainable cities, identified that there is more the Commonwealth government could do to improve energy efficiency in its own vast operations. This point was taken up by the Sustainable cities report in recommendation 25:

quote.para: Â ... that Australian Government departments and agencies that own property take steps to improve the sustainability of those buildings, at least to the 5 star rating, and that departments and agencies that rent property consider measures to improve building efficiency when seeking tenancy agreements.

speech.para: I think anyone looking at todayâs bill would say that that is fair enough. If it is good enough for us to require the private sector to assess its energy efficiency and change its practices, it is certainly good enough for the Commonwealth government to do the same.

However, in highlighting these deficiencies in the bill before us, we must be careful not to toss the baby out with the bathwater. So the bill does have our support, and it is worth examining this proposal further, as I believe there is some merit in it. It seeks to add to the range of measures introduced by governments over the course of the last decade, to address the challenges of climate change and environmental degradation facing our country. In drawing attention to these problems, the opposition cannot be accused of scaremongering or exaggeration. The situation is spelled out in detail and backed up by scientific evidence from independent sources such as the regular state of the environment reports and the CSIRO, among many others.

As I said, the measure in this bill is the latest in a list of initiatives aimed at improving energy efficiency and reducing greenhouse gas emissions, dating back to the National Greenhouse Response Strategy agreed to by the Council of Australian Governments in 1992. For example, in 1995 the Keating government established a Greenhouse Challenge Office, which was charged with the task of liaising with industry enterprises. In June 1996, the initial group of industry bodies signed up their commitment to the Greenhouse Challenge. With the voluntary agreements in place, by 1999 there were commitments to reduce greenhouse gas emissions relating to over 250 important sites across Australia.

Meanwhile, the Industrial Energy Efficiency Project undertaken by the Warren Centre for Advanced Engineering at the University of Sydney had a primary aim to demonstrate to Australian industry the financial benefits of energy efficiency. It was to show how significant savings can be achieved through the application of inexpensive, cost-justified techniques. The project, which ran from 1997 through to 1999, was built on five case studies that would each highlight techniques to increase energy efficiency and which can be applied widely throughout Australian industry. Around 60 specific opportunities for energy savings were identified across the five case studies. Nearly a third of the opportunities related to better measurement and control, and a further quarter called for improvements to operational procedures.

The experiences learned from these case studies demonstrate the need for this bill. Greater energy efficiency can be achieved and businesses will see a benefit to their bottom line. The question remains, though, whether they will take that next step and make the investment required to implement the changes identified. Nothing in this bill answers that question, so it will be interesting to see the results of this particular program down the track.

The potential for businesses to make a difference to overall energy consumption and consequently the impact on our environment is enormous. According to the Warren Centre study I referred to earlier, total energy consumption for Australia is 3,000 petajoules per annum, and it is estimated to cost $40 billion annually. Industrial energy consumption is 40 per cent of this, amounting to an energy bill of $16 billion per year. Experience in Australia and overseas has demonstrated that it is possible to save 10 to 15 per cent of this over a five-year program. This would result in reduced costs of up to $2 billion annually, strengthening Australian industry and making it more competitive in world markets. We know that these changes can happen and they can make a difference.

I have seen examples of some very successful energy efficiency programs in my electorate. These programs have been run at local primary schools, and the results of the energy efficiency measures, designed and monitored by students, have been very encouraging. They show that it is possible to change our behaviour and habits and that even small changes can yield significant results. The programs I am talking about were run under the state governmentâs Energy Efficiency in Schools Program. The model developed and trialled so successfully in Central Queensland has now been expanded to other areas of the state.

We are very lucky to have the North Keppel Island Environment Education Centre in my electorate. Greg Hossack, the Principal of the Environment Education Centre, has been a key driver in developing the program in partnership with the Environment Protection Agency, Education Queensland and electricity supplier Ergon. The purpose of the program is to get students to design action plans to reduce energy usage at school and at home. First of all, principals sign up their schools to the program and commit to reducing energy usage at their school by 15 per cent. Another component of the program involved selected students from various schools in Central Queensland being immersed in a values based program.

The program commences at their school with audits of energy, waste and water and then incorporates a residential component at the North Keppel Island Environment Education Centre. The students also travel to visit other schools, power stations, alternative energy sites and industries committed to the Greenhouse Challenge. Students are provided with opportunities to see how global warming has impacted on our environment. You do not have to go too far in Central Queenslandâthe Great Barrier Reef obviously is feeling the effects of climate change already. They also see ways to reduce energy consumption. Students and teachers armed with that knowledge and experience then jointly develop and implement an action plan for their school.

I was very fortunate to attend a ceremony at Gracemere State School a couple of months ago at the culmination of that schoolâs participation in this program. Gracemere is one of three schools in my immediate district that have undertaken this program in the last few years, and the results were absolutely astonishing. The students involved put an action plan into place and really showed a great deal of leadership in driving that action plan and changing the way that all students and staff at the school approached energy use in that school. As I said, the schools commit to reducing their energy consumption by 15 per cent when they sign up to this program, but Gracemere State School was able to achieve a 28 per cent reduction in energy use at their school over the course of the program. For that achievement they were awarded a $3,000 grant by the state government, and that grant will allow the school to undertake further projects, improve facilities and put up things like curtains and awnings to help reduce energy use even further.

Other schools in the district who have been involved include Lakes Creek State School, which I believe managed to reduce their energy consumption by about 25 per cent. They have managed to hold that reduction steady for a number of years now, which is quite amazing when you think about how hot it gets in Central Queensland. They have got airconditioners and all sorts of things to keep the environment pleasant enough, but they have still managed to reduce their energy consumption by 25 per cent from its base level. The other school that participated is Byfield State School, a very small school up in the state forestry area north of Yeppoon. They managed to cut their energy use by 47 per cent, which is a great achievement. It was really interesting to hear the students talking about what they had learned and the impact that the program had had on them. They had really started to see the world in a different way, to see their impact on that world and the way that they could change their habits and behaviours to improve things. I really do congratulate all the students and staff from those three schools who have been involved in this program. I think that, if primary school students can show us how to achieve those kinds of energy efficiencies, it puts the onus back on to large corporations to do the same thing when this bill comes into place.

This is an important issue, because we have many sobering references to the state of the environment worldwide. Successive state and federal governments in Australia have been searching for that optimal policy mix of regulation, legislation, voluntary action and community led answers. But we have seen even from the latest state of the environment report that those years of effort and the billions of dollars that have been spent in this area have still not guaranteed us a sustainable future in Australia. That is why I welcome any new initiative from the government in this area. It is also why we must not stop with this initiative; we must continue to seek answers for future generations.

There is no doubt that the role of the corporate sector is a very important one in driving these very important changes. My seat is a regional one, so my interest is particularly with initiatives by corporations that have been successful in regional Australia. I believe that the more Australia responds to the need to lower greenhouse emissions the greater will be the shift of energy production to regional Australia. This will mean more local jobs and less centralised power generation. Clearly the provision of low-cost, reliable power to a region can promote regional development, attracting both the establishment of new businesses and the expansion of existing ones. A new low-cost energy source can attract major new investments with associated employment and spin-off benefits for a region.

It is interesting to see the member for Kennedy here, because I am about to talk about his electorate. The Townsville City Council estimates that the Carpentaria gas pipeline to Mount Isa triggered $4.5 billion worth of investment in the Queensland north-west minerals province. While electricity is generally regarded as an essential service, access to natural gas is still quite scarce in regional Australia. The majority of gas reserves developed in Australia have been a long way from the large demand centres, and this has typically led to long gas transmission pipelines from gas fields to larger cities. As a result, regional areas that happen to be adjacent to these transmission pipelines have a much greater likelihood of being able to economically access gas supplies. These energy supplies have been available for some time, and Australiaâs good corporate citizens have already been putting them to good use. Another example of the private sector showing the way in this area is the $400 million pulp mill built by Visy Industries at Tumut, in New South Wales. It is very well known for the way it has set up its operations to be very environmentally sustainable.

Of course, there are other examples of corporations which are working towards achieving energy efficiency. One other example I wish to refer to today is just one of the projects championed by the Rockhampton based Stanwell Corporation. This project involved the construction of 20 wind turbines with a generation capacity of 12 megawattsâagain in the member for Kennedyâs electorate, I believeâat Windy Hill near Ravenshoe on the Atherton Tableland in North Queensland. Built by Stanwell Corporation, it provides electric power to the grid. A second stage could see the building of a further 22 turbines. About 10 to 15 per cent of the $20 million construction cost was spent locally, with a small number of construction jobs. There will be three local ongoing operational jobs. However, the major direct benefit has been in visitor numbers, with 84,000 visitors to the area to see the wind farm in just three months. The wind farm has revitalised the tourism industry in the area. A long-term indirect benefit of this type of development is that regions will increasingly source their power locally, thereby reducing their dependence on electricity imported from distant generators. This avoids heavy power losses from long-distance transmission and is therefore a major contributor to the efficient use of energy in the Atherton Tableland area. The Windy Hill project is an early example of how regional Australia can benefit from measures to improve energy efficiency and cut greenhouse gases.

Of the examples I have given, oneâthe Visy projectâis purely a private enterprise project, while the Windy Hill project was carried out by a Queensland government owned corporation. These programs relate to the use of alternative fuel and renewable energy, gas, wind power and biomass energy, and these projects were the early movers for regional Australia. However, given the rapid technological improvements taking place in almost all forms of renewable energy, there are several new industries which I would have hoped would have been well established by now. The opportunities I refer to include tidal power, solar, mini-hydro, geothermal, ethanol and biodiesel.

It is my belief that the development of these technologies depends crucially on the extent to which governments introduce measures to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and the extent to which the federal government is prepared to go in giving leadership and a national direction to industry. It is a great failing in this bill by this government. Good corporate citizens like Visy and Stanwell are already out there seeking opportunities and bringing them to fruition, but there is still a long way to go. Many of our largest energy usersâfor example, large office towersâare not subject to this scheme. Many of them, as well as our other not-so-good corporate citizens, will continue to ignore the real need to improve energy efficiency until the government introduces appropriate legislation which will include time lines for corporations to implement and reach predetermined energy inefficiencies.
Debate interrupted.

talk.start.para: (Hon. BK Bishop)âI wish to inform the members that we have present in the gallery members of the staff of the Afghan national assembly. The staff members are visiting Australia to observe the operations of our parliament. On behalf of the committee, I extended a very warm welcome to them.

âI acknowledge the presence in the Main Committee of the visitors from Afghanistan. A significant percentage of my electorate migrated from Afghanistan. They have played a very important part in the history of Australia and some of them are the biggest livestock hauliers in Australia today. So I acknowledge the visitorâs presence.

speech.para: Ever since the Phoenicians invented money we have had an excellent measure for scarcity, but unfortunately probably also an excellent measure for monopoly in military powerâthey also reflect money values. But let us get back to the scarcity issue. It is no use us talking about energy usage when in a country such as India a 2,000-megawatt power station was built by Enron that never sent out a single electron of electricity because the people there could not afford to pay to have electricity in their homes. So when we talk about energy, we must also talk about its cost effectiveness. The whole tenor of the debate on the Energy Efficiency Opportunities Bill 2005 has gone sideways. There are no worries about using huge amounts of energy so long as you recycle the commodities instead of putting vast volumes of CO into the atmosphere. Let us look at CO, because that is really what we are talking about here. If you can use energy and it makes no change to the environment, then by all means use it. It can extend and enrich all of our lives, as it could have done in India with that huge power station at Dabhol.

Having said all of those things, I move very swiftly to the issue of ethanol, because so many of the energy problems in this country are solved immediately by the use of ethanol. We use about 20,000 megalitres of petrol in our motor vehicles every year. If 10 per cent of that is an ethanol blend and five per cent of that comes from sugarcaneâand I cannot speak with authority on the grains industry, but I think it is reasonable to assume that about half of that will come from sugarcaneâat 15 tonnes of sugar per hectare and at 650 litres of ethanol per tonne of sugar, that gives us 10,000 litres per hectare of ethanol we can produce every year. To meet the five per cent requirement, it would require 100,000 hectares of land to be put under farm land, since the water resources of the Gulf of Carpentaria and Queenslandâs mid-west are literally unlimited. The water and land resources at the present moment grow virtually nothing at all, so the carbon absorption levels at the present moment are virtually negligible. We get a flashy three months of rain and then we get nothing for the next nine months, and a lot of our trees die every year, but we do not have many trees to start with. In fact, on the great black soil plain we had no trees at all until a filthy pest arrived, but it probably is a net producer of carbon rather than the other way round.

Sugar is CHO. Therefore an absorption of around eight million tonnes of CO per year would occur on 100,000 hectares. I want to emphasise that these figures are very rough; I have not had time to do the accurate work that probably should have been done. If we in Australia move to a 50 per cent ethanol blend, as we should and as we inevitably will, 80 million tonnes of our annual CO emissions of 405 million tonnesâone-fifthâwill be absorbed by this industry.

Let me explain two or three things. It is to the great shame of CSIRO that one of its officers reported that sugarcane is not necessarily a net user of CO. He had not rung up a single sugarcane farmer or a single sugarcane miller. I asked him what CO was emitted from the production of sugar. He said, âYouâve got tractors, for starters.â I said, âHow many times do you think a tractor would run down the rows in a year?â He said: âSeven times. Youâve got cultivation and planting.â I had to inform him that we do not plant sugarcaneâor we plant it every six years. We do not do any of those things. He did not know this.

Then the CSIRO officer said, âYouâve got pesticides and those sorts of things.â I said: âWe now have a trash blanket of nearly a foot of material on top of the ground. We donât burn cane anymore and we donât need pesticides much at all because the cane is the only plant powerful enough to push up through the trash blanket.â He said, âYouâve still got your milling process.â I said, âHow much CO do you think that would put up?â He said, âYouâve got all the energy usage.â I said, âWeâre net energy suppliers to the electricity grid.â

I do not say these things to criticise CSIRO, although they very much deserve to be trenchantly criticised for that outrageous report. But I do bring these things to the attention of the parliament, because one-fifth of Australiaâs CO emissions can be absorbed by simply moving to 50 per cent ethanol in petrol.

Ever since the Phoenicians invented money that has been a very serious issue. We do not want to end up like the Indians who built a 2,000-megawatt power station and did not use any electricity. Can we afford to do this?

I did not believe it, so I had to get a photograph. I had to get a photograph of a bowser where people sold petrol over in Brazil. It says â1.359 real per litroâ. Translating that into Australian currency, it is 68c a litre. People pull up at the bowser and fill up their motor cars at 68c a litre. The WTO has already decided that there is no subsidisation involved in the petrol market or the sugar market in Brazil. We have the opportunity to move to 68c a litre and have our own indigenous source of petrol to overcome a fifth of our CO emissions. Why has this country not moved on it? There is no explanation for this except the condemnation of the government.

Let me move on. I was the mines and energy minister in the Queensland parliament and I had various other ministerial responsibilities that led me into this area to some great degree. I chaired a number of the state and national alternative energy seminars and conferences at the time. If the government had survived in 1989, we would have moved all government housing and all welfare housingâwhich is about a quarter or maybe a third of all housing in Queenslandâover to solar hot water systems. As the energy minister, I knew that that would have postponed for 15 years the requirement for another 1,000-megawatt power station. I cannot give the exact figures for that, but it seemed to meâand I looked at the figures again this morningâthat there would be about a six per cent energy saving in the state of Queensland simply by moving all of those houses to solar power.

I do not want to stand hereâI most certainly am not a socialistâand say we are going to do these things. Have a look at the costs and whether they are practical. For a mass buy of solar hot water systems, we are looking at an install price of about $2,000 per house, and of course the energy saving on electricity would be about $200 a year. So in fact people could actually end up in front. The electricity costs for the poor people on welfare housing would actually be moderately reduced, and we would still pay off the solar hot water system, whose expected life span is about 30 or 40 years. What a magnificent move forward in energy saving. That can be done tomorrow by any government.

Let me turn to the power stations. In Australia wherever humanly possible all of our energy sources should be turned to electricity. We advocated very strongly a program, which we would have enforced one way or another, as we were wont in Queensland, where hire car companies at the airport would have available electric vehicles. These cars do not do huge mileages. They just cruise around the city. Of course it is a very cost-effective way of producing a vehicle. The cost of running a vehicle that way was about $1 a day versus about $6 or $7 a day. The car hire is about $150 a day. But the real cost of running that car was about $1 for its energy requirementsâand about $2 otherwiseâbecause electric cars are very cheap to run.

Underneath the Story Bridge in Brisbane there is space for 2,000 cars. It is vacant space. We wanted eight major lanes of traffic coming onto and going off the Story Bridge. Instead of that traffic going on into the CBD area, we wanted the cars to park under that bridge, and a mobile walkway would take the people into the city. If you take a car weighing 2,000 kilograms into the city, that uses a lot of energy. You could take a person who weighs 70 kilograms into the city, and since they would walk a little bit on those mobile walkways they might even lose a few kilos on their morning walk. It was a walk of about 500 or 600 metres to reach virtually any part of the city under that arrangement. There would have been colossal savings in energy, and the reduction in pollution for the CBD area of Brisbane was massive. I am not saying that every city would be as well set up to do that as Brisbane. It would also cut magnificently traffic congestion in the city. We had two other sites that we were looking at that would have moved in that direction, but unfortunately the government fell that year.

Another initiative which was taken by that government is very important here. We were involved in the biggest solar energy project in the world. All of the Torres Straitânot a huge population; about 5,000 people scattered over about 20 islandsâwas to come under solar energy. Madam Deputy Speaker Bishop, you would be well aware that I most certainly am no environmentalist. I always class myself as an anti-green. The reason I was doing this was thatâsince the Phoenicians invented moneyâit was one hell of a lot cheaper for the state government to go to solar than to go to the alternatives of coal or diesel, because it was so far away and because of the cost of getting it there. In fact, when we mixed a little bit of wind energy with it, there was an $8 million saving to go to photovoltaic cells as opposed to going to a diesel or coal alternative, out of a total life cycle cost of about $30 million. So it was a third saving in cost.

This precipitated a huge contract, which General Electric in the United States were desperately after. In fact they offered me a free tour of all of their installations in the United States, which I rejected. The reason they were so anxious was that it was the biggest ever contract. We said, âWe will give it to you on one condition: that you buy your silicon from Australia, from our resource at Shelburne Bay.â

The Shelburne Bay project was worth $4,000 million a year to the Australian economy. It was to mine 200,000 tonnes a year of pure silicon. At that time the price of pure silicon meant that it was worth $4,000 million to the Australian economy. It is a 99.98 per cent super pure rich deposit and is all ground up for youâit is in very fine sand. It is blowing into the ocean, so there is no environmental issue. So that was worth $4,000 million and we could produce electricity from solar energyâduring daylight hours, I would emphasiseâat competitive prices with grid system power. It was competitive with grid system power and the project was worth $4,000 million to the Australian economy.

In spite of pleading on my bended knees with the incoming government, the incoming minister, the Premier and all of the departmental officials, that area is now a national park. That sand dune is so âvaluableâ that within 100 years it will not exist at all. It is already 200 metres into the ocean. Aerial photographs will show you. It was a navigation aid at the turn of the century, and in 100 years half of it has gone. In the next 100 years the other half will be gone. It now has not one iota of value to the Australian people, and of course it is vanishing, so I hardly think it is going to have any great heritage value as a declared heritage area. Maybe we can leave a monument there to the stupidity of the incoming socialist government that followed us. That dune is still there at this stage.

talk.start.para: âWhat about nuclear power?

âNuclear power? Why do we want to go down a difficult road? Let me return to the power stations we do have. I come from one of the most coal-rich states on earth and obviously, like all Queenslanders, have a prejudice for coal. I serve on a committee in this place and we had the figures put before us of the cost of production of powerâGod bless the Phoenicians for inventing moneyâin the United States. The figures were US1.7c for a kilowatt hour in the United States, 1.8 cents for coal-fired power and 5.8 cents for gas-fired power. Obviously we want to go to the cheapest one, and since we have coal more abundantly than the United States we can produce for even less. It is one-third the price of its alternative.

speech.para: You can come in here and say, âNo, we are not going to use coal; weâre going to use wind and hydro and all of these other things.â All right; if the poor people are willing to pay three times what they are currently paying for electricity, it is a good idea. Maybe it is 10 times on present figuresâI did not include those figures in the cost, but it is about 10c a unit for hydro and about 12c or 15c a unit for wind generation. Do you want to clear the rainforest? The only reason we were able to have Windy Hill in North Queensland was that it was a cleared rainforest area. All of our high points have jungle on them. I for one am not in favour of clearing that jungle. You need to be looking at serious alternatives.

If there is a problem, I do not think the scientific case has been made out on CO. But I do not think anyone here would question the fact that putting increasingly large volumes of CO in the atmosphere is going to create some problems, somehow, somewhere. So we want to cut that down.

I would plead with people to understand a tiny bit about science. CO is carbon and oxygen mixed up together. Oxygen is very valuableâwe breathe it and it is wonderful to have a lot of oxygen around the place. As far as the carbon goes, the last time I looked at the figures we were importing about $100 million of activated carbon, which is almost pure carbon in a particular form. We were importing $200 million worth of urea, which is mainly carbon, into this country. The aluminium industry imports another $70 million and the tyre industry another $70 million, $80 million or $100 million worth of carbon.

Wouldnât it be nice to get the carbon from an indigenous source? There is no great difficulty with this. If real, fair dinkum, scientific money is applied, then we can work out ways of taking that carbon and turning it into a valuable resource for this country. To cite one example, a 1,000-megawatt power station is capable of producing an unbelievable $5,000 million worth of urea. I have some difficulty in believing that, but those are the figures that were handed to me. As far as the solid matter from a power station goes, with electrolytic precipitation and with baghouse technologyâa very simple technologyâwe can take 99.98 per cent of the solid matter out of what is going out of the smokestacks at electricity stations. So do not be worried about having a carbon power station; do something about it. (Time expired)

talker.name: Entsch, Warren, MP
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources
talker.name: Mr ENTSCH

talk.start.para: âin replyâThat is going to be a very hard act to follow. I have just been going through my closing speech, and I certainly do not have all those statistics available in it. But I will do the best that I can. I would like to thank the members who have contributed to the debate on the Energy Efficiency Opportunities Bill 2005, particularly the member for Kennedy, who gave a most entertaining speech. I hope that we will now see agreement to this bill, which establishes the mandatory energy efficiency opportunities assessments announced in the governmentâs energy white paper Securing Australiaâs energy future in June 2004.

speech.para: The energy white paper identified the improvement of Australiaâs energy efficiency performance as a key part of the governmentâs energy policy in order to achieve greater prosperity, sustainability and energy security. The energy efficiency opportunities measure is directed at improved business energy efficiency, which will reduce the growth in demand for energy and reduce growth in emissions and which will also delay the need to install and operate new energy generation capacity.

To establish this measure, the bill sets out the broad requirements of large energy-using businesses to assess the potential to improve their energy efficiency and report publicly on the outcomes. It allows for regulation making to provide detailed requirements for assessment, reporting and verification and other elements of the program. The regulations are being developed in intensive and comprehensive consultations with industry and with other government agencies to develop a practical scheme that does not unnecessarily duplicate other programs. Investment in energy efficiency opportunities will be at the commercial discretion of the businesses. This approach enables large energy users to demonstrate to the community that they are efficiently managing their energy, without the government becoming involved in commercial decisions.

Importantly, a key measure of the effectiveness of the program will be how well companies take up the energy efficiency opportunities they identify. We want the measure to be the spur for the leaders of large energy-using businesses to understand their energy use and improve their energy efficiency and to enable them to demonstrate to the community that they use energy responsibly. For many this may mean a substantial shift in thinking, but there is clear evidence to show that businesses can achieve more than they thought possible when opportunities are really considered. Leading from the top is the only way to make a real impact on energy use and help to make Australiaâs energy future more prosperous, more sustainable and more secure.

I have here a correction to the explanatory memorandum for the bill, which I would like to table. This makes clear that paragraph 25(1)(b) of the bill, which allows suitably qualified persons to be appointed to undertake verification and compliance inspections, does not have an unrestricted scope. Persons appointed must have suitable qualifications in the particular business and technical fields where they will be doing inspections. Suitable qualifications may substantially differ for inspection of different companies and business sectors. The points that the opposition has attempted to score in its proposed amendment to the second reading motion are certainly off target.

The Australian government is raising the standard on energy efficiency across all sectors of the economy, as demonstrated by its commitments in the 2004 energy white paper for more stringent minimum standards and requirements in appliances, equipment and residential and commercial buildings. In the transport sector, the government is pursuing greater energy efficiency through a range of measures, such as targets to reduce national average fuel consumption, the Green Vehicles Guide and TravelSmart to encourage better transport choices. The government is also pushing hard to keep improving the energy efficiency of government agencies.

The government also works with the states and territories to encourage better coordination of national efforts, because many of the regulatory powers in these areas are held by other levels of government. The National Framework for Energy Efficiency, endorsed by the Ministerial Council on Energy in 2004, provides a stronger framework for coordination of energy efficiency programs in the residential, commercial and industrial sectors.

Criticism of the governmentâs support for renewable energy is misplaced. Since 1996 the government has provided a record level of support for the renewable energy industry. The most significant single initiative is the mandatory renewable energy target, which has stimulated over $1 billion in renewable energy investment, with an additional $1 billion either committed or planned. It will also create some 3,000 jobs in the renewable energy industry. I would suggest that those figures would be a lot more credible than some of the figures that we heard bandied around here a little while ago.

From 1996 to 2004 the government allocated more than $300 million to renewable energy development and uptake through a range of programs. Then, in the energy white paper of 2004, the government made another $700 million available to support low emission technologies, including renewable energy. That is $1 billion directly provided by the government and a program that has directly stimulated an extra $2 billion in investment. That shows how seriously we support clean energy from all sources.

This government has also demonstrated its support for alternative fuels. The governmentâs fuel excise reforms will provide alternative fuels with an effective excise free status until 2010. From 2010 excise will be incurred in five equal steps until 2015, where the final excise rate will be applied, with alternative fuels receiving a 50 per cent discount on excise rates. In addition, the government has granted $36.7 million for biofuels projects under the Capital Grants program and has paid more than $41 million in ethanol production grants. The Prime Minister has reaffirmed the governmentâs commitment to the 350-megalitre biofuels target, and the government is working with industry to achieve those targets.

The oppositionâs amendment also raises the Sustainable cities report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Heritage. This report was only tabled on 12 September 2005, and that is why the government is yet to respond. It would be ridiculous to expect us to make a half-baked, off-the-cuff response as soon as the report was tabled. The government takes the report seriously and wants to respond seriously. The report is currently being reviewed by relevant agencies and is the subject of consultation. A formal government response to the Sustainable cities report is planned to be tabled in the first half of 2006.

talker.name: Hunt, Gregory, MP
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage
talker.name: Mr HUNT

talk.start.para: âI move:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

speech.para: The main purpose of this bill is to insert a new interpretive provision, section 15AE, into the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.

New section 15AE will explain what is meant when a provision of a law provides for the making of an instrument which is described as being a legislative instrument and what is meant when a provision of a law provides for the making of an instrument which is described as not being a legislative instrument. This new section was requested by the Office of Parliamentary Counsel to make the drafting and interpretation of provisions dealing with legislative instruments clearer and simpler. It will make clear that, wherever the term âlegislative instrumentâ appears in legislation, it has a particular meaning. This will simplify drafting practice as it removes the need to define the term âlegislative instrumentâ every time it is used in legislation.

New section 15AE provides that instruments that are described as legislative instruments must be in writing and are legislative instruments for the purposes of the Legislative Instruments Act 2003. The Legislative Instruments Act provides that a legislative instrument is an instrument in writing that is of a legislative character and that is or was made in the exercise of a power delegated by the parliament. This amendment is a technical amendment and will not affect the substance of the law. It will not expand or restrict the operation of the Legislative Instruments Act. The amendment will operate from the commencement of the legislative instruments legislation on 1 January 2005 and has no adverse effects.

The bill also makes a number of consequential amendments to provisions in Part XI of the Acts Interpretation Act. The provisions in that part were inserted by the Legislative Instruments (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Act 2003 to preserve the operation of the Acts Interpretation Act in relation to non-legislative instruments. The proposed consequential amendments to these provisions of the Acts Interpretation Act are drafting changes only in consequence of the insertion of new section 15AE and make no substantive changes to the Acts Interpretation Act.

Finally, the bill will amend the Acts Interpretation Act to clarify the operation and meaning of certain provisions and phrases in part V of the Legislative Instruments Act 2003 when applied to disallowable non-legislative instruments. The amendment was requested by the Office of the Parliamentary Counsel to clarify aspects of the relationship between the Acts Interpretation Act and the Legislative Instruments Act for the benefit of users. I commend the bill to the House and I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill.

talk.start.para: âLabor supports the Acts Interpretation Amendment (Legislative Instruments) Bill 2005 to simplify legislative drafting in the light of the commencement of the Legislative Instruments Act 2004 earlier this year. As the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage has indicated, the bill will insert a new section 15AE into the Acts Interpretation Act 1901. This section will provide a central definition of âlegislative instrumentâ so that drafters do not have to provide this definition every time they make reference to a legislative instrument in another bill. This is a definitional section which will have no substantive effect on the operation of the Commonwealthâs statutes.

speech.para: We understand from the explanatory memorandum that this change was proposed and is supported by the Office of the Parliamentary Counsel. That office is essential to the operation of this parliament. Over recent decades the office has maintained very high standards of legislative drafting in this country by paying careful attention to consistency, clarity, structure and plain English. As that office believes that this amendment will make its job easier and our statutes clearer, Labor is pleased to support the amendment.

talk.start.para: âIt is a good thing the honourable member for Gellibrand is not being paid by the word, because she would not get a lot of performance pay for the number of words that she uttered on the Acts Interpretation Amendment (Legislative Instruments) Bill 2005. This bill does not, however, requireâ
âItâs quality, not quantity, Peter.

âI do not in any way, shape for form wish to derogate from the quality of your brief but significant contribution on the bill. Having said that, to fill in 20 minutes on the bill one would have to read into Hansard the explanatory memorandum and the bill. But you will be pleased, Madam Deputy Speaker, to know that I do not intend to follow that particular course of action.
âHear, hear!

âI thank my friend and colleague the member for Fairfax for his concurrence. When acts of parliament are drafted it is the intention of those writing the legislation that the document be both as comprehensive as possible and as clear and workable as possible. The purpose of the Acts Interpretation Amendment (Legislative Instruments) Bill 2005 is to insert a simple definition into the Acts Interpretation Act 1901, thereby helping to clarify, simplify and guide the interpretation of those acts written since then.

speech.para: The definition that is being sought to be inserted by this bill is that for the term âlegislative instrumentâ. It will define the difference between when a law allows for the making of an instrument that is classed as a legislative instrument and it will also define when the law provides for the making of an instrument that is not a legislative instrument.

The changes suggested by the bill are of a definitional nature and will, therefore, as the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage pointed out, have a minimal effect. The inclusion of these terms and provisions will, however, put an end to the need to add a definition for âlegislative instrumentâ in every new law as it is drafted.

The Acts Interpretation Act 1901 is exactly that: a sort of guidebook that lists definitions and common procedures that are applicable for all acts of parliamentâfrom definitions and explanations for simple terms such as the âcommencementâ of an act, the date of assent, repealing an act and the expiration of an act, through to rules for the use of headings, schedules, marginal notes, footnotes and endnotes, as well as clarification of items such as the power of an act in Australian waters, references to the role of His Excellency the Governor-General and the accepted measurement of time and distances as it applies in all Australian acts, to name a few.

The Acts Interpretation Act 1901 is one of those pieces of legislation that could be described as dry. If I could borrow a term commonly used by some media organisations when describing mundane stories: it is not a particularly sexy act of the parliament.

The Acts Interpretation Act 1901 may be rather mundane but it is a vital piece of legislation in that it outlines many of the foundational devices and procedures that determine the validity and operation of every single act of parliament. It sets out in black and white definitions for many of the terms, present in our other acts, that the large proportion of members probably take for granted. It is one of those acts that does not seem to have any great purpose on its own, but is in fact both a fundamental and a vital companion to all other acts. It is the act by which the meaning of other acts is determined.

When one buys a new electrical appliance, it can be somewhat foolish to start using that appliance without first reading the handbookâbut, of course, if your new TV is the 10th TV you have owned, you may have the experience and confidence to use it without consulting the handbook. Nonetheless, the handbook is there ready in case you find yourself in trouble. It is similar with the Acts Interpretation Act 1901. It may not be consulted often, because much of its contents may be regarded as common knowledge among those in this House, but the actâs contents are, notwithstanding, particularly important.

The modifications suggested by the Acts Interpretation Amendment (Legislative Instruments) Bill 2005 will further enhance the usefulness and indispensability of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901. I am particularly pleased to commend this amending bill to the Main Committee.

talker.name: Hunt, Gregory, MP
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage
talker.name: Mr HUNT

talk.start.para: âIn setting out closing comments on the Acts Interpretation Amendment (Legislative Instruments) Bill 2005, I wish to note very briefly the eloquent and moving contribution of my friend and colleague the member for Fisher. In examining this topic, he has demonstrated a command of legislative history that is rare and unusual in the parliament. It was perhaps the most moving paean to the Acts Interpretation Actâa much neglected and underappreciated actâin the history of either the Main Committee or the central chamber. That the act has a fan, a champion and a supporter is good to know. I am sure that the Office of Parliamentary Counsel will be appreciative.

speech.para: I also wish to acknowledge the words of the member for Gellibrand, who, in a brief but eloquent speech, noted the important work of the Office of Parliamentary Counsel. That is a significant thing and one which we should do. We recognise the role of the Office of Parliamentary Counsel.

Very simply, this bill does a simple thing. It sets in place a definition that applies to all legislation. It removes the need for duplication and replication across all subsequent bills. I commend the bill to the House and I thank all of those involved in its production and generation.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
Ordered that this bill be reported to the House without amendment.

debateinfo.title: CONSULAR PRIVILEGES AND IMMUNITIES AMENDMENT BILL 2005

motionnospeech.name: Mr BILLSON
motionnospeech.role: âParliamentary Secretary (Foreign Affairs) and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs)

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

motionnospeech.para: This bill amends the Consular Privileges and Immunities Act 1972 to allow for additional privileges and immunities to be granted on a reciprocal basis to consular officers representing overseas countries in Australia. The Consular Privileges and Immunities Act incorporates specific articles of the Vienna Convention on Consular Relations into Australian law. The convention governs the conduct of consular relations between nation states and establishes the privileges and immunities of consular posts and associated persons.

At the time the convention was drafted in 1963, the drafters envisaged that the convention might not cover all possible situations and circumstances affecting consular relations. Therefore, the convention contemplates that statesâ parties could extend additional privileges and immunities to other nation states through custom or agreement.

The changed overseas operating environment since the convention was drafted in 1963 calls for reflection on whether the interests of Australiaâs consular officers serving overseas are, in all situations, offered the most appropriate protection available. This bill sets in place a framework within which Australia can negotiate, on a country-by-country basis, enhanced protections for persons performing consular duties on behalf of the Australian government overseas. In response, Australia will offer reciprocal treatment to consular officials from overseas countries undertaking consular functions in Australia.

The main provision of this bill sets out the conditions under which Australia will grant additional privileges and immunities to an overseas country. The bill requires an agreement, arrangement or understandingâcalled a âreciprocal instrumentâ in the billâto be entered into between Australia and an overseas country. This will grant reciprocal privileges or immunities, or both, which supplement, extend or amplify the provisions of the Vienna Convention on Consular Relations.

The amendment to the act will not of itself grant additional privileges or immunities. In order for additional privileges or immunities to be granted, the Minister for Foreign Affairs must determine that the section will apply to a specific country and the reciprocal instrument must be in place. In line with growing international practice in this field, the granting of privileges or immunities will be negotiated bilaterally on a reciprocal basis. The bill also provides that any privileges or immunities shall be extended only for so long as the ministerâs determination and the reciprocal instrument are in force.

The amendment facilitates the making of arrangements which will appropriately provide for the changed operating environment of consular officials both in Australia and overseas. I present the explanatory memorandum to the bill.

talk.start.para: (Hon. BK Bishop)âThe question is that this bill be now read a second time. I call the honourable member for Slipperâfor Fisher.
âThank you, Madam Deputy Speaker. To have an electorate named after one, as you almost named one after me, indicates that one, in most cases, must be deceased.
âExactly.

âI think Dame Annabelle Rankin actually had an electorate named after her while she was alive, but it is not something that happens very often. I am very happy to be the member for Fisher, which of course is on Queenslandâs wonderful Sunshine Coast.

speech.para: The Consular Privileges and Immunities Amendment Bill 2005 is about strengthening Australiaâs relationships with other nations. The long-term presence in Australiaâmostly in Canberra but also in Sydney, Brisbane, Melbourne, Perth and, on occasions, other state capital citiesâof government officials from other countries and the comparable ability of Australian officials to reside in other countries goes a long way towards encouraging stronger international ties. What better way to understand and appreciate the nation that one is dealing with, that we might be negotiating with, than to live amongst its peoples and to observe its customs and traditions from within on a daily basis. And diplomatic representation has been one of those ongoing traditions over the centuries.

Australia has a significant number of officials based in other countriesâstaff at approximately 160 embassies, high commissions, consulates, multilateral missions and representative offices in nations from Angola, Argentina and Austria through to Zimbabwe and many in between. Some nations have more than one Australian office. For example, the United States, a very important ally of Australia, has 12. The Peopleâs Republic of China, which is developing its relationship with Australia very strongly, is a nation where Australia has four consular offices.

Many of these nations recognise that it is equally important to have consular officials based here. They recognise the value I mentioned earlier of being stationed on the ground within Australia, as opposed to the disadvantages of trying to conduct international relations from an office thousands of kilometres away. It is a pity that we cannot actually have more resident diplomatic personnel in other countries, but I do appreciate that the Minister for Foreign Affairs is given finite resources and must, therefore, prioritise where we do have residential representation as opposed to non-residential representation.

Those officials from other countries who agree to come here, who are living away from home, are carrying out a very important role and working long hours and they are, quite naturally, extended various privileges. The majority of the privileges and immunities available to be conferred on these welcome visitors are set out in the international agreement, the Vienna convention on consular relations. The Consular Privileges and Immunities Amendment Bill 2005 proposes to introduce changes to the Consular Privileges and Immunities Act 1972 that will enable Australia to make reciprocal commitments for additional privileges for consular offices, and this was indicated by the Parliamentary Secretary (Foreign Affairs) in his second reading speech.

This is only fitting in the ever-changing world of international relations to ensure our relationships with other sovereign nations are given every opportunity to be as strong as possible. The provisions of this bill will encourage stronger relationships between Australia and other nations. The assigning of privileges to visiting consular officials is something that can no longer be set in concrete. The needs of officials from one particular nation, for instance, will be different to the needs and requests from those of other nations. The system for granting these privileges must be fluid and flexible, and that flexibility is encouraged by the Consular Privileges and Immunities Amendment Bill 2005.
New reciprocal agreements negotiated between Australia and another country will further facilitate the goals of the Vienna convention on consular relations introduced in Vienna in 1963, which notes:

quote.para: â¦ that consular relations have been established between peoples since ancient times,

Having in mind the Purposes and Principles of the Charter of the United Nations concerning the sovereign equality of States, the maintenance of international peace and security, and the promotion of friendly relations among nationsâ

speech.para: while also, and I quote furtherâ

quote.para: â¦ Believing that an international convention on consular relations, privileges and immunities would also contribute to the development of friendly relations among nations, irrespective of their differing constitutional and social systems,

Realizing that the purpose of such privileges and immunities is not to benefit individuals but to ensure the efficient performance of functions by consular posts on behalf of their respective States â¦

speech.para: The Consular Privileges and Immunities Amendment Bill 2005 supports these very admirable goals. The changes outlined in the Consular Privileges and Immunities Amendment Bill 2005 will not themselves confer new privileges and immunities, but they will introduce the power to confer additional privileges and immunities.

Further requirements outlined in the bill include that the Minister for Foreign Affairs must declare that the new section of the law will apply to a particular country and that the additional privileges and immunities will be negotiated between officials from Australia and from the nation in question. It is important to note that in Australia, through the provisions of this bill, we will not be handing out new privileges on a whim. The bill will give Australia the ability to respond to requests made by other nations for certain consular privileges, for example, but any agreements or arrangements that are introduced will be entered into only on the basis that they will be in Australiaâs interest and on the basis of reciprocity. If we give something to visiting consular officials, we will also expect to receive something for our own overseas staff.

The legislative changes suggested by this bill, although applicable only in Australia, will have the effect of enabling our country to negotiate more favourable conditions, privileges and immunities for our own diplomatic officers who are working overseas. In a global climate in which international relationships are dependent on respect, flexibility and friendship, the provisions of this bill, as outlined by the parliamentary secretary, will help to further strengthen Australiaâs invaluable partnerships with other countries. I am pleased to be able to commend the Consular Privileges and Immunities Amendment Bill 2005 to the House.

talk.start.para: âLabor supports the Consular Privileges and Immunities Amendment Bill 2005 to amend the Consular Privileges and Immunities Act 1972 to expand the range of consular privileges and immunities that can be afforded to foreign consular officials in Australia above and beyond those provided under the Vienna Convention on Consular Relations. The act gives legislative force to the Vienna convention in Australia.

speech.para: The Vienna Convention on Consular Relations and the Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations are multilateral treaties, ratified in the 1960s, which codify centuries of international customary law and practice on diplomatic and consular relations between states. The conventions set out the functions of diplomatic and consular missions and officials and a range of privileges and immunities which diplomatic and consular officials are to be afforded by the receiving state. The preambles of both conventions clearly state that the purpose of such privileges and immunities is not to benefit individual officers but to ensure the efficient performance of the functions of diplomatic and consular missions in the territory of the receiving state.

That is firmly Laborâs view. Labor supports the granting of privileges and immunities as a means of facilitating smooth and efficient international relations, rather than as a means of conferring any form of personal advantage on consular or diplomatic officials working in Australia. Similarly, Labor is strongly of the view that Australian consular and diplomatic officials must not abuse their position as a representative of the Australian government and misuse the privileges and immunities they enjoy overseas. Labor notes that this bill relates only to consular privileges and immunities and not to diplomatic privileges and immunities.

The bill aims to give flexibility to enter into agreements with other states to grant privileges and immunities to consular officers above and beyond those provided for in the consular convention on a reciprocal basis. Article 73(2) of the Vienna Convention on Consular Relations envisages that bilateral agreements may be made between states to supplement, extend or amplify the provisions of the consular convention. Labor acknowledge that it is therefore arguable that the government already has the power to grant such enhanced privileges and immunities. We welcome the move through this bill to clarify and make transparent the use of that power and welcome the fact that, in the process, the bill also restricts the use of the power to circumstances where Australia has entered into a reciprocal arrangement with the country concerned.

Labor recognises the important role of consular officers in representing Australian interests overseas. The role of consular officers includes issuing emergency passports or travel documents; providing assistance to Australian travellers in distressâfor example, in the case of an accident, serious illness or death; arranging for next of kin in Australia to be notified when something goes wrong; providing assistance to Australian travellers who are arrested overseas; conducting prison visits for Australians detained overseas; and providing assistance during emergencies such as natural disasters and civil uprisings.

Labor congratulates Australian consular officials on their outstanding performance, often under intense pressure, in recent yearsâin particular, the consular response to the Bali bombings on 12 October 2002, the Indian Ocean tsunami on 26 December 2004 and the most recent Bali bombings only a few weeks ago.

The number of Australians travelling overseas is increasing each year. In 1996 there were 2.7 million short-term international departures by Australian residents and by 2004 this had increased to 4.4 million. It is not surprising that this has led to an increase in demand for consular services and has increased the pressure on our hardworking consular officers. What is surprising, however, is that over that period DFAT staffing levels have decreased by 29 per cent. What we see in the budget papers this year confirms that consular staff are likely to continue to remain under pressure. Despite the raft of difficult consular cases that have come to public attention in the past year, including the responses to the Indian Ocean tsunami and to the Schappelle Corby and Bali nine cases in Indonesia and to the Dobbins case in Costa Rica, there has been a staffing increase of just four staff for outcome 2 of the DFAT budget, which includes consular and passport services.

With the introduction of the new e-passport, it is likely that what paltry number of extra staff there will be under outcome 2 will be taken up on the passport side of the equation. Of course, Labor welcomes any extra staff and resources for the passports operations area of the department. Labor has recently raised its concern about the security of the Australian passport system. Whilst the minister, Mr Downer, told Lateline on 28 April 2005 that 2,000 missing Australian passports was a tiny number, we cannot agree with that. It appears that Mr Downer is spending too much time jockeying for the deputy leadership of the Liberal Party and not enough time focusing on the core responsibilities of his department. Information obtained by Labor confirms that up to 2,500 Australian passports remain unaccounted for, as they have not reached their intended destination by post. Labor has been able to establish through parliamentary questions on notice that over 1,000 Australian passports remain unaccounted for in the past three years alone.

On 31 December 1997 the minister dropped the requirement that his department send out Australian passports by registered post. We can confirm that between 31 December 1997 and 22 July 2002, when he reinstated the requirement to use registered post, at least 2,042 passports were recorded as missing and, at the time of our receipt of questions on notice, 1,435 passports still remained unaccounted for.

In the 2003-04 financial year, 1,302 Australian passports were recorded as missing and, of those, 1,076 still remain unaccounted for as of February this year. This comes on top of the disclosure from DFAT that one of the Bali nine was employed in the Sydney passports office in 2000 and the news that Indonesian authorities are claiming that some of the Bali nine were using multiple passports. The minister talks all the time about national security, but security first and foremost begins at home. As a matter of urgency, the minister must tell the Australian public what has happened to the up to 2,500 Australian passports that remain unaccounted for, and whether it is possible that any of these passports could have been used for improper purposes in support of transnational crime.

talker.name: Billson, Bruce, MP
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary (Foreign Affairs) and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs)
talker.name: Mr BILLSON

talk.start.para: âin replyâIt is a pleasure to sum up the debate on this important legislation, the Consular Privileges and Immunities Amendment Bill 2005. The demand on consular services has grown dramatically over recent years, as both the member for Fisher and the member for Charlton in their contributions have recognised. Ordinary travellers are facing difficulties overseas, and Australians are travelling in greater numbers than ever before. At times there are major consular crises due toâsadly, in some casesâterrorism, sometimes natural disasters, sometimes misfortune or sometimes just a disappointing set of circumstances. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has responded to this demand by putting more effort and focus into managing consular cases, both here in Canberra and at our overseas posts.

speech.para: The consular area is both well resourced and remarkably resourceful. The people on the ground are experienced and innovative, as you have seen from the example of the hurricane in the United States. It was an Australian official that gained first access to the area after the hurricane using their local savvy and knowledge, supported by the excellent diplomatic, consular and country-to-country relationships that we maintain.

An example of this is our Consular Emergency Centre, which we set up to provide 24-hour assistance to Australians in trouble overseas and give immediate guidance to our posts on consular cases. Another is the comprehensive advice we provide to Australians through our Smart Traveller web siteâwww.smartraveller.gov.au is definitely a must-see destination for any Australian planning overseas travel.

The proposed amendment to the Consular Privileges and Immunities Act is a further way in which we can try to better safeguard the interests of the travelling public and our Australian consular officers operating overseas. The Vienna Convention on Consular Relations was developed at a time when work of consular posts was limited to a traditional idea of assisting individuals in troubles overseas. The role of a consular officer has expanded enormously to the point where more and more they are called upon to provide quasi-diplomatic functions as part of their duties. They do not, however, enjoy the same immunities as a diplomat. For example, diplomats are granted full immunity from criminal jurisdiction and almost full immunity from civil and administrative jurisdictions in the country in which they operate. Consular officers are granted immunity only in relation to their official functions as outlined in the consular convention.

Australia maintains a significant consular presence in commercial centres such as Bali, Ho Chi Minh City, Chicago, Guangzhou and Shanghai. It may in some circumstances be appropriate to seek greater protections for our consular officers in those areas commensurate with the broad range of functions which our consular officers perform. The Consular Privileges and Immunities Amendment Bill 2005 will enable Australia to negotiate additional immunities for Australian consular staff in major commercial centres which are not capital cities or the site of our primary embassy.

The Consular Privileges and Immunities Amendment Bill 2005 might also be of benefit to Australiaâs interests in terms of the additional protections we could negotiate for Australian locally engaged staff performing consular functions overseas. Australian practice is to provide locally engaged staff operating in foreign consulates in Australia with immunities in relation to their official functions. This is not guaranteed by the consular convention; it is a matter that is left to individual countries to determine. Not all countries provide these immunities to locally engaged staff, and this limits the nature of the functions that Australian locally engaged staff can perform overseas. For example, the fact that locally engaged staff can be called to give evidence in a court proceeding against an Australian consular client means that in some circumstances we must limit the direct involvement of locally engaged staff in providing consular assistance to Australians. Strategic negotiation of additional immunities for locally engaged staff could improve the service we can deliver to Australian citizens overseas while protecting Australiaâs national interests.

The consular convention provides safeguards in relation to the privileges and immunities granted by the consular convention. The consular convention is premised on the fact that privileges and immunities that are granted by it are for the efficient performance of functions by consular posts, and not to benefit individuals. The Australian government has always taken a responsible approach to the way immunities and privileges are applied in practice. The consular convention also provides that all persons enjoying privileges and immunities are under a duty to respect the laws and regulations of the country they operate within.

The immunity of an individual can be waived by their home country. In the case of Australian personnel serving overseas, it is government policy to waive immunity in all but the most exceptional circumstances. For example, the government may not waive immunity where there are inadequate legal systems in place. This is a decision that is taken by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and not the individual concerned.

In the case of individuals enjoying immunity in Australia, it is our policy to seek a waiver of immunity from the relevant country in order to enable the administrative and judicial system in Australia to arbitrate the matter in accordance with Australian laws and regulations. If the country declines to provide a waiver of immunity, Australia has the option of declaring staff members of a foreign mission unacceptable. This process is known as persona non grata, and it obliges the foreign mission to arrange for the individual concerned to be recalled to their home country or to terminate their functions with the consular post. It is in very exceptional circumstances that Australia would also have the option of severing consular and/or diplomatic ties with the country concerned.

The member for Charlton mentioned the issue of passports. Australia has a world-class passport system, one that is envied around the world. Most recently we have seen the e-passport system enabled in Australia, introducing biometrics as a further security measure, protecting identities and protecting our national interest. As I said, our passport is regarded as one of the most secure in the world. It has tamper resistant features and any attempt to substitute data would be immediately evident.

The shadow foreign affairs minister has long gone on about this subject, as if suggesting that lost passportsâthose that might slide down the back of the cushion on the couch at homeâsomehow represent a compelling and immediate terrorist or security risk. He fails to understand the fact that those tamper resistant features guard against the substitution of new information. He also fails to understand, as has been explained repeatedly, that all passports reported as lost are immediately cancelled in the passport-issuing system, so they cannot be used to leave or enter Australia. A lost passport is something that needs to be identified and recovered, and that is a shared responsibility including the passport holder. But the passport that is lost is not operative. So this is part of the system that seeks to ensure that we have one of the most secure systems in the world.

Since July 2002 all clients within Australia have received their passports by registered mail. Since this time there has been a dramatic reduction, by at least 90 per cent, of the passports reported as missing in the mail. But I emphasise again that a missing passport is made inoperative and cannot be used to steal someoneâs identity or to penetrate the security arrangements that protect our passport as being one of the most secure in the world. The new Passports Act, which came into effect on 1 July, includes tougher penalties for passport fraud, and measures aimed at reducing the number of passports lost. I know the shadow minister keeps on talking about that but fails to grasp some of the essential issues he should consider.

In conclusion, the amendment contained in the bill will enable the government to respond to the changing overseas operating environment in line with the growing international practice in this area. The changes will allow Australia to negotiate on a case-by-case basis more comprehensive privileges and immunities for Australian consular officers serving overseas where the local operating environment makes this appropriate or necessary. In return, the amendment permits the government to offer specific countries reciprocal immunities for their consular officers serving in Australia where this is in the national interest.

I would like to thank the competent staff of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, particularly James Larsen, Suzanne McCourt, Stacey Morgan, Simeon Gilding and all of those in the Consular Operations Branch and the Legal Branch of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. They do a remarkable job and they are outstanding professionals. I commend this bill to the House.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
Ordered that this bill be reported to the House without amendment.

subdebate.2.para: Debate resumed from 12 September, on motion by Mr Barresi:

motion.para: That the House take note of the report.
