talk.start.para: âThere is a growing national debate about the health of our cities, and the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Heritage has played a critical role in fostering that debate. The committee report has 32 recommendations, all of which deserve serious consideration by government. It is important to note that this is a bipartisan report. This is the parliament of Australia working at its best. It is a very comprehensive report, as looking at the chapters that are included in it would indicate: a vision for sustainable cities, sustainability in cities, governance and policy frameworks, planning and settlement patterns, transport, water, building design and management, energy, and research and feedback. They have all contributed to quite a comprehensive approach to Australia moving towards sustainable cities.

speech.para: It is important to note that the report begins with a quote from Mr Chris Davis, the CEO of the Australian Water Association. That quote is: âSustainability is a journey, not a destination.â That is important because at the moment the Commonwealth government has retreated from activity and involvement in a direct sense in ensuring we do take steps on that journey towards sustainability. Everyone seems to have an opinion about the health of our cities, but the Commonwealth in the last decade has retreated from that direct involvement. That has not always been the case.

Perhaps the best two periods of involvement in recent times have been, in 1972, the creation of the Department of Urban and Regional Development under Tom Uren, and the historic changes that were made by the Commonwealth in providing sewerage, in providing essential services and in increasing the quality of life for those people who live in our cities. The Better Cities Program, under Brian Howe, provides another blueprint for how this can occur. An example is the city of Newcastle. When the steelworks shut down in Newcastle there was considerable comment and doom and gloom about what that would mean for that city. Yet Newcastle today is a thriving centre. It is thriving in part because of the involvement of the Commonwealth. It is also surviving, of course, because communities need to take action themselves. But they need to be supported by government.

At the moment there is not a national strategy for our cities. The truth is that the sustainability sections of the Department of the Environment and Heritage are very limited in resources, personnel and research from the Commonwealth government. I am the shadow minister for water. If you look at who on the government side is in charge of water, it is very difficult. There is no counterpart. It is split up: there is a bit in the Department of the Environment and Heritage, a bit in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and a bit in the Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry. We actually need to do better on these issues, and the Commonwealth has an absolutely critical role to play. That is not just Laborâs view. That is the message from hundreds of submissions to the landmark parliamentary inquiry into the health of our cities. I pay tribute to every single member of the committee, coalition and Labor, for this report, because it points a way forward to the federal government playing that leadership role in restoring the health of our cities.

Our cities are running out of water. Every capital city in the nation has water restrictions. Power blackouts have occurred in Perth, and blackouts are possible in other areas. Adelaide is seeing the effects of a dying Murray River. Nationwide our infrastructure is crumbling. Just last week South Australians received a huge wake-up call, with warnings that Adelaide could potentially turn into an urban wasteland within 30 years. Seventy-five top scientists warned that unless we did the right thing by our environment we could lose thousands of unique plant and animal species in Adelaide alone.

Labor and Liberal members of the environment committee were all concerned that Australia is going backwards on nearly every indicator of environmental health. That is why they have recommended establishing an Australian sustainability charter that sets national targets for all the key indicators of environmental health, including water, energy and transport. That is why they have recommended establishing an independent sustainability commission, which would administer sustainability payments to states and territories and would monitor the performance of governments across agreed targets. That is a level of accountability which simply is not there at the moment. It is one that could have prevented a decade of mismanagement of the environment and ensured national leadership when it is sorely needed.

The Standing Committee on Environment and Heritage has made some valuable conclusions. It has reminded us that the federal government has a major role to play in delivering reliable public transport in our major cities. In most industrialised countries, this is acknowledged. That is why the US federal government provides substantial funding for urban transport infrastructure. The report reminds us of the health, social and environmental benefits of investing in cycling infrastructure. It reminds us of the crucial role that the federal government can play in setting strong standards for energy and water efficiency. These are important recommendations that will be closely examined by Labor as it develops its policies in the lead-up to the next election.

It is a new reform agenda but, of course, it is not new territory for the Labor Party, as shown by the Chifley government in introducing the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement; the Whitlam government, with Tom Uren and DIRD; and the Hawke-Keating governments with the Better Cities Program. We need fresh hope, new ideas and an investment in healthy cities. The environment committee has given us some clear directions in its report, but equally interesting about its report is what is missing. It has ignored our greatest environmental challenge: climate changeâand I think that is the one weakness in the report.

In its previous inquiry into green jobs, the committee recommended that the Howard government increase quite substantially the mandatory renewable energy target as part of a multifaceted approach to increased market demand for and supply of renewable energyâa bipartisan recommendation, rejected by the government and on which there has been no action. As a result, the committee report provides an important road map towards building healthier cities, but critical pages are missing from that road map. There is no reference to the dramatic impact climate change will have on our coasts and urban areas, and it has not recommended the solutions that are sorely needed.

The government need only look at its own report, the Climate change: risk and vulnerability report, which was given to it in July. This report estimates that Australia could be two degrees hotter by 2030. This would be devastating for our coastal and urban areas, with more severe wind speeds in cyclones, more severe heatwaves and bushfires and reduced rainfall in southern Australia, with catastrophic consequences for water. Climate change is one of the greatest challenges faced by our cities, and we cannot be left unprepared for that challenge. Australia requires an urgent plan of action that tackles climate change as the focal point of a sustainable cities strategy. This strategy must include ratifying the Kyoto protocol, establishing a national greenhouse emissions trading scheme and establishing an ambitious mandatory renewable energy target. Of course, this is just a first step, but you have to crawl before you can walk.

The first meeting of the parties to the Kyoto protocol will be held in Canada next month. Tony Blair is right to say that the challenge is what will come next, after 2012. Will it be another round of division or will it be what we need: a sound, rational, science based unity that ensures the right legally binding framework to incentivise sustainable development? We simply cannot rely upon voluntary agreements. We need binding agreements to move forward. We need action in Australia and globally.

Australiaâs greenhouse pollution is set to increase by 23 per cent by 2020âmost of this in citiesâthrough increases in energy and transport in particular, so we need a plan of action. Renewable energy is an important part of that plan of action. The committee has made two good recommendations to the government: that the government double the photovoltaic rebate to further encourage the uptake of photovoltaic systems and that it further develop its commitment to energy sustainability. This is very important. It will provide not just domestic benefits but also, potentially, export benefits. The program has been given a two-year extension, but that is all. We need an increase, as the committee has recognised. Industry also needs more certainties; it needs long-term programs.

The committee was also right to encourage state and territory governments to mandate disclosure of the energy efficiency and greenhouse performance of residences at point of sale and point of lease. The truth is that much more can be done in relation to energy efficiency. We should view the challenge as an opportunity. There is ample proof that energy efficiency can deliver economic growth for the economy and greater profits for business.

The Climate Group, a UK based non-profit organisation, recently reported that 43 companies had significantly reduced their greenhouse gas emissions and saved a total of $15 billion. I also commend to the House a recent report from the Climate Group which provided case studies of 15 major cities around the world, including Melbourne, which have set ambitious targets for emissions reductions. There is much that we can learn from their experiences. We desperately need a new approach that places environmental sustainability at the heart of government, with a recognition that sustainability is as much an economic and social challenge as an environmental challenge.

Labor will continue to talk about the need for national leadership to restore the health of our cities. Just last week, Kim Beazley outlined a blueprint for developing a more diverse transport fuel industry, which is good for the environment, good for the economy and good for our health. Under the blueprint, Labor would make alternative-fuel vehicles tariff free, cutting up to $2,000 off the price of current hybrid cars; work with state and local government to give city traffic and parking advantages for these vehicles; and examine the greening of tax rebates for converting petrol cars to LPG. These are important measures that would make a difference to the health of our cities and the health of Australians.

According to the Bureau of Transport and Regional Economics, pollution from cars is contributing to as many as 2,000 premature deaths in Australia. Traffic fumes are causing at least 2,000 asthma attacks annually. The Sydney Morning Herald reported on 30 July 2005 that several of Sydneyâs suburbs, particularly those near major roads, are exposed to high levels of air particles containing pollutants that can cause breathing problems. Car fumes are blamed for 55 per cent of the particles detected in the air in Sydneyâs CBD. Marrickville, Concord, Lane Cove and Bankstown have some of the highest shares of vehicle emissions. It is simply not good enough in this day and age that 2,000 Australians could die prematurely just because of where they live. We must invest in clean fuels. This must be a part of our investment in healthy cities.

I congratulate the chair of the committee, the member for Moore, but I congratulate particularly the deputy chair of the committee; she has been deputy chair over the life of two parliaments. The deputy chair, my friend and comrade the member for Throsby, Jennie George, is also the shadow parliamentary secretary for environment and heritage and is driving Laborâs agendaâLaborâs commitmentâto the sustainability of our cities.

This is an important report. I encourage the government to take up its recommendations, because the withdrawal of the Commonwealth government from involvement in our cities is simply not good enough. If this government will not fix it, Labor in government will. Once again, like the Chifley, Whitlam, Hawke and Keating governments, we will see the Commonwealth once again play the important role that it has to play in driving a sustainability agenda for our cities. I commend the report to the House.

talk.start.para: âI endorse the remarks of the previous speaker, the member for Grayndler, in his recognition of the two members, the member for Dunkley and the member for Moore, who have chaired this inquiry into sustainable cities. To them and to the deputy chair of the committee go my heartfelt congratulations on the production of this report. However, to me, this report is a compilation of this committeeâs ideas, dreams and visions rather than a direction to follow. I think this report is at its best in opening up ideas and challenging others to look at the parts of the report that they would be most interested in. It should be a textbookâI was going to say for Australian schoolsâfor the nation. It is unlike all other reports.

speech.para: Today in this parliament and around the country we have heard news reports that the changes the government is making to other legislation within this House and in the other house will affect the lives of every person in Australia. That may or may not be the truth. Other legislation coming before us is to protect the lives of every person in Australia.

This report and these recommendations are about the future liveability of this nation, the future liveability of our cities and the future liveability of our homes, our streets. They are about the way we interact with one another and whether we can sustain the life we have been living.

In my maiden speech I spoke about sewerage and how important sewerage was to me at that time, because I had just come off being a member of the Pakenham Sewerage Authority, a very august body. I was also a member of the Mornington Peninsula and District Water Board, which tripled in size under Minister White at the time of the Cain government. I was appointed to that board also, which was eventually consumed by Melbourne Water. Throughout that time I had the great opportunity to be forced to look at water issues from the top of the catchment to the bottom of the catchmentâfrom the beginning to the endâand how we addressed them. Later on I had the opportunity under the Kennett government to be on the board that reformed local government in Victoria. Part of that processâfor different reasons, some political but some physicalâwas deciding where to draw the boundaries of the new areas.

In discussions at home one time we looked at the catchments and how important the catchments were to where people lived and how they operated. With people doing damage in the hills by clearing, which affects the people at the bottom of the catchment, why should we not have been joining those people together? If you look at the boundaries of the new local government areas in Victoria today you will find that, except for some political argy-bargy, they are basically built on the catchments right across Victoria. They were all catchment shires, as best we could make them. It put the people at the top of the chain together with the people at the bottom of the chain. So even then we were thinking about the sustainability of communities and of catchmentsâdrawing people together so that they had equal responsibility from one end to the other.

In this report there is a whole chapter on water. It provides a lead as to where cities might consider going, how they should be addressing the issues they are confrontingâparticularly Perth, Adelaide and Sydney. The report talks about these places being on the edge of a cliff. It is a tale of two cities. One city, Perth, is recognising that it has a water problem and is addressing those issues. The other city, Sydney, seems to be turning its back on the water issues that it needs to be considering.

So there is purposely no criticism of past programs. In fact, there is praise of past programs, such as the Better Cities Program under Brian Howe, which I was around for, and other programs that have all been part of what the federal government has been doingâand all governments have been doing. All governments have been talking about this issue.

Going right back to my first time in this parliament, in the nineties, we were talking about water as being a major issue. But it was not until we were confronted by a long-term drought, from 1992 up until last year, that we were forced in each community to face up to water issues. We forced our organisations then to really ask how we were going to address it. What did they do first? Put the price up. That is the first thing you do. That was a poor reaction because it affects the poorest people. Why canât people who have less income be allowed to have the same garden as somebody else who has a greater income? As a community, those are serious things that we should be looking at. Water pricing is not just a matter of putting the price of water up and it does not reduce consumption to the point that you would expect pricing to do. So restrictions went on.

This week in Canberraâthank heaven!âthe water restrictions are off, and this place is turning green again. It has been a long, dry time this last 12 months I have been here. One could see that looking at the surrounds of the parliament. I am one Australian that is very proud of the parliamentary gardens and the way they are presented to the national and international visitors who come to what I call the beautiful township of Canberra. Canberra gets knocked a lot, Mr Deputy Speaker McMullan, as you may know. It is the butt of jokes right across the nation because it is the political capital. But, as far as liveability goes, you can breathe in the national capital; the way it has been designed and laid out with its trees and its buildings, it is a beautiful place in which to live and work. I sell that to my community: this is a beautiful place to visit. It is a great place to come and see.

What a difference the water has made. There was parched land, parched lawn and brown everywhere. Today the restrictions are off, the lawns are turning green, things are looking good and I think people are feeling better because of it. I am not saying the drought is over. People are now far more careful with the water they use. In the parliament they have just put water savers throughout the building. So parliament is playing its role in saving water.

We have been talking about recycling water since the 1990s, but have we done something about it? In some places we have. There is a very special program on the Murray River. The community there have spent $40 million to recycle every drop of waste water. They are recycling 100 per cent of their waste water and putting it back into their community to use. It is not going into the Murray and running through the river system without being totally cleaned first. In the Latrobe Valley, just outside my electorate, there is a wonderful wetlands area under the purview of the catchment management authority down there, the Morwell Wetlandsâit was John Mitchellâs dream. The power companies have played a role in it. The river has been diverted. The water is cleaned before it lands back in the streams and rivers that flow into the ocean.

Water has been an issue but it did not really get a top run until such time as we were without it. The Sustainable cities report was written during drought. Many decisions have been made by state governments in the last two years in drought conditions. Hopefully, those drought conditions will end. I believe that Lake Eildon is now heading towards 60 per cent fill; the rivers and streams are being filled as we speak. It is raining in Tasmania at the moment and there is rain predicted for Melbourne tomorrowâand the rain is hitting in the catchment areas, which is making a huge difference. At the same time, Toowoomba is desperateâand Toowoomba is in a huge rain belt.

The weather patterns seem to have changed, but I believe it is a cycle and that it will come around. So I did not want the member for Grayndler to be promoting the climate change issue, which he seems to be fixated on. We should take this time to consider the nationâs water needs but we should not be locked into one program. That is why the vision for sustainable cities outlined in this report is a very broad indicator of directions for the future. The recommendations are not designed to lay down laws, restrictions and prescriptions. This report provides an opportunity for others to take up the vision. The other day I was not only talking about the federal government taking a leadership role. That is importantâit is in the report. We should take a leadership role where we can and where we are allowed to take such a role, without crossing into the statesâ area. But it is also important to have a relationship between federal, state and local and community bodies. This report sends out a message that we need a whole-of-nation response. Let us not talk about a whole-of-government response. The response is ours. The response is in our homes. The response has to happen at an individual level, where we desire to make a difference and ensure a sustainable future, not only for our cities but for our nation as a whole.

When the committee had a roundtable meeting the other dayâand I will finish on these remarks to allow more time for the member for Throsbyâthe ACF was one of the presenters. We have moved on in a bipartisan way on the environment so far. When I was a candidate in the 1984 and 1987 election campaigns, the main people handing out against me were the ACF, and I have never forgotten it. I see those signs every time they present anywhere.

It was a reminder to me of just how far we as a nation have moved on that we no longer see as radical those people we saw as radical all that time ago: we see them as quite sensible. Is that because we all want to have a crack at making a real difference to the environment and the sustainability of our cities? I think so. I think there is a great deal of bipartisan support for this report. It will not be a report that lies in dust on the shelves of membersâ offices.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I thank you for the opportunity to speak about this report today. I congratulate all of the members of the committee. Sitting in that room with those members and seeing the vitality of their desire in relation to this report made it for me a pleasure to participate as a backbench member of the government. I recommend the report.

talk.start.para: âMr Deputy Speaker McMullan, you would know personally, from your long experience in parliament, that the work of committees such as the Standing Committee on Environment and Heritage can be a very stimulating and rewarding part of our work as backbenchers in this parliament. It is particularly rewarding if the government takes seriously the content and recommendations that flow from reportsâthat reports do not just sit on the bookshelf to be forgotten.

speech.para: In a sense I am reasonably lucky, because the committees that I have had the opportunity to participate in have been very stimulating. The first one produced the very important report Every picture tells a story, out of which we now see very comprehensive changes to the Family Law Act, which affects so many people. The report we are discussing today, Sustainable cities, is another report that I hope will have positive and long-lasting outcomes.

As deputy chair of the committee, I want to thank the many organisations and individuals who gave freely of their time, in both the hundreds of written submissions and the roundtable discussions we had with a cross-section of important community organisations. I thank very much all those who contributed, for their efforts and their ideas. I also want to thank my colleagues on the committee. As you will note, Mr Deputy Speaker, the recommendations are bipartisan on an issue which historically had the potential to see members adopt party political stances on a range of key issues. That did not happen. I want to particularly thank Bruce Billson, the former chair, and the member for Moore for ensuring a constructive engagement by all on the committee. That is not to say that everything that I would have likedâ

talk.start.para: âI can tell that you tried hard.
âI tried hard, but you cannot win them all. But I think the recommendations that arise from this report are worthy of serious consideration.

speech.para: The report came at a very good time. More and more Australians are beginning to realise and lament the decline in the health of our cities. There is one city that I know most about, and that is the city of Sydney. I want to place on record my thanks to the Herald newspaper for the series that they ran on different key issues confronting a city that they say is a city in crisis.

I want to refer to a number of issues raised in the series. Fifty years ago, half of all journeys to work in Sydney were by train. Now fewer than 10 per cent are by train. There has been a 15 per cent growth in the distances cars travel each year. There are a million more people tipped to come to Sydney in the next 20 years. That means that 650,000 additional homes will be needed, 70 per cent of them squeezed into existing suburbs. The series talks about the problems of Sydneyâs water supply and the fact that 11 per cent of Sydneyâs water is being lost through leaky pipes. It talks about the growth in energy use, which is nearly triple the population growth.

Series like this raise the consciousness of people about some of the very important issues that affect, after all, the overwhelming majority of Australians, 87 per cent of whom reside in our cities and suburbs. I think people are beginning to appreciate that there is something going drastically wrong. They appreciate that when they are faced with water shortages and with power blackouts and when they look at rivers that are dying, the lack of public and accessible transport, the congestion that occurs in cities and our crumbling infrastructure. All those issues are germane to the public debate and discourse that we need in trying to shape a road map for the future. I really do believe that the recommendations and the content of our report will help fill in the pieces of that road map in a pretty creative way.

The environmental statistics we point to in the report paint a very bleak picture of the effects of unsustainable practices. And with an increasing concentration of population in both urban and coastal areasâlike the region my colleague the member for Richmond representsâthe case for action on sustainability is becoming imperative and urgent. However, I cannot refrain from saying that the Howard government does need to engage, provide leadership and recognise that a national government has a central role to play in this debate. Failures in this regard were noted by so many submissions to the inquiry. It is not an issue I am raising out of context, as many submissions said we urgently need a new national focus on the health of our cities.

The committee believes that sustainability is as much an economic and social challenge as an environmental one. We have recommended a new governance structure to drive the sustainability agenda from the national level. The committee has recommended the creation of an independent Australian sustainability commission, which will monitor the extent to which all levels of government adhere to and promote a COAG agreed set of sustainability targets. We see these targets across a range of key areas, including water, transport and energy. The committee really believes its sustainability reform can be a driver of future productivity and economic growth. In the words of the national president of the Planning Institute of Australia, one of the numerous bodies that made contributions to our report:

quote.para: ... we must not think of sustainable cities as being some sort of cost that we have to bear in the interests of a greener and more sustainable future. The fact is that, if we had sustainable cities, there would be a significant productivity dividend to the country. In other words, GDP would be greater, other things being equal, if we had better functioning and efficient cities.

speech.para: The committee believes the federal government can contribute positively through funding arrangements that we have recommended. We believe that the idea of incentive payments for sustainability outcomes warrants further consideration.

In all, we have made 32 recommendations across a key range of areas including transport, water, building design, energy and research. No doubt a number of our recommendations are innovative, and I dare say a bit controversial. I guess that is the role of committees: to stimulate discussion, to generate ideas and public debate. Among our recommendations are the following: that the government should review the FBT concessions for car use; that funds for public transport, particularly for light and heavy rail, be increased and integrated into overall national funding in this area; that the first home owner grant should be increased to $10,000 for homes that meet stringent sustainability criteria; that there should be a national five-star rating for homes; that the National Water Commission should prepare an independent report on water options for cities and regional centres; and that the benefits of using recycled water be promoted through an information and education campaign. Our recommendations underpin a set of principles for sustainable cities in the future, cities which are economically productive, environmentally responsible and socially inclusive.

I am disappointed that there was one failing in the reportâwhich, in my view is a significant failingâin that we did not give the priority required to tackle our greatest environmental challenge: climate change. A previous inquiry by the same committee recommended that the government substantially increase the mandatory renewable energy target as part of a multifaceted approach to increasing market demand for and supply of renewable energy. That proposition was not picked up again, obviously because the Howard government has abandoned any commitment to increase the MRET, but I do believe it is a vital element to any road map for the future.

The responses to our report to date have been very positive and encouraging. We have had support from a range of groups, including environmental groups, the Labor Party and the Greens. We have also had favourable responses from important bodies such as the Planning Institute, the Association of Architects and the Chief Executive of the Property Council, who are all on the public record as welcoming the recommendations in our report.
I want to finish by quoting some comments made in an interesting editorial in the Sydney Morning Herald following the release of our report. The editorial begins:

quote.para: Astonishing unanimity has broken out in Canberra. Labor and Coalition MPs agree drastic action is necessary to make Australiaâs cities more liveable â¦ Approval may not be universal, but it is close. Why then do we suspect nothing will come of it?

speech.para: That is an interesting question. The editorial goes on to say that the Sydney Morning Herald had documented over a period of time and in some detail the governmentâs record of responses to reports from parliamentary committees. It concluded that the response of the government was tardy; in fact, the word they used was âabysmalâ. Too many reports had languished and the recommendations had never been given due and proper consideration by the minister and by this government. The Sydney Morning Herald urged the government to respond to this report because, in the view of the editorial writer, many of the committeeâs ideas had merit. The editorial said:

quote.para: A federal sustainability apparatus might add some stiffening to state politiciansâ pliable spines.
Despite its lack of broad responsibility, the Commonwealth is not powerlessâ

speech.para: in this important field of endeavour. The editorial continues:

quote.para: The Commonwealth should do more to help those cities become better places to live. The reportâs recommendations are a good start.

First, though, the report must negotiate the bureaucracy. It is in the hands of the Environment Minister, Ian Campbell. We await his response with interest. In the meantime, the MPs on the committee should keep the pressure on the Government to ensure their work does not go to waste

speech.para: I am very confident that the members of the committee, who in a cooperative spirit worked so constructively to produce this report, are all very committed to ensuring that the minister does respond in a timely manner to many of the recommendations contained in this report. Some of the most far-reaching recommendations go to the new structural arrangements that we envisage, whereby the national government can provide a leadership roleâa visionary roleâbut can also provide the levers, through funding arrangements, which will ensure that the sustainability agenda is driven at all levels of government.

As I said in my opening remarks, one of the interesting and challenging jobs that many of us do as backbenchers is to participate in the work of a range of parliamentary committees. I have been lucky enough to have worked on a number of committees that have provided the opportunity for fundamental changes in attitudes and have made recommendations that go to the heart of the legislative changes that are necessary in the national interest.

I conclude by saying that I trust that the contents of this report and the 30-odd recommendations that we have made in itâsome of which are quite innovative and controversialâwill at least be given due and proper recognition and consideration by this government. All the submissions that came before the committee lamented the fact that the national government had withdrawn from this area of important public policy, and they felt that there was an important need for a national vision about sustainable cities into the future and that sustainability principles ought to be considered along with bottom line indicators, like economic and social outcomes, to ensure that the people of this great nation can continue to live in communities and cities that are sustainable in the long term.
Debate (on motion by Mr Neville) adjourned.

motion.para: That the Main Committee do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: âI want to take the opportunity this afternoon to place on the parliamentary record my appreciation of the work of PHocus, a local lobby group that has been working with the involvement of and in consultation with the NRMA to improve the state of the Princes Highway, which runs through my electorate of Throsby. They want to see additional funds come from both state and federal governments to undertake the urgent upgrade of that highway. Central to their objective is to secure funding to ensure a four-lane dual carriageway north of the Jervis Bay turnoff and further down the highway to enable full B-double access, particularly between Nowra and Bega. To achieve this outcome they have estimated that an extra $400 million would be required on the basis of a shared arrangement between state and federal governments.

speech.para: The safety record of the Princes Highway is well known and is nothing short of a national disgrace. Between 1994 and 2003, the Princes Highway saw 6,803 crashes, 3,989 injuries and, appallingly, the loss of 138 lives. The worst-performing section of that route, based on crash rates, with both the crash and casualty rate being more than 60 per cent above the route average, is the Shellharbour local government area in my electorate of Throsby. It is in this part of my electorate, at Yallah, where the highway changes from a high-standard dual carriageway to a two-lane undivided rural road in most parts.

This highway is under intense pressure as it struggles to service a growing population, with many people taking part in the sea change that is a growing phenomenon in Australia and moving down to the beautiful South Coast area of New South Wales. It is struggling to cope with not only a growing population but also, because of the beauty of the region, a high volume of holiday road users. You only have to drive down it at holiday times to understand the pressure that is being created.

Much of the publicity about the highway has focused to date on the highwayâs appalling safety record. More recently, debate has been expanded to include consideration of the highwayâs economic significance to our region. I must say that when the member for Cunningham and I met with the PHocus lobby group we said to them that we needed to take the next step and try and convince the government and the opposition of the economic benefits that would flow from an investment of substantial extra money into upgrading the highway. Much to our delight, PHocus have provided a detailed economic analysis of the economic variables that are so necessary in ensuring that the region can rely on the highway as an important contributor to future economic growth. What people need to appreciate is that beyond Bomaderry the Princes Highway is the only land transport artery for the region. In this regard, the highway supports the economic development of the Illawarra and the South Coast. It is a major infrastructure asset and it is vital to this regionâs future economic growth.

The key results of the findings show that there would be net economic benefits derived from the proposed highway upgrade which would yield positive net present values ranging from $611 million to $1.05 billion over the next 30 years. Those benefits would come through travel time savings, avoidance of crash costs, and B-double productivity gains.

I question why the Princes Highway has been neglected by this federal government. Why isnât it part of the governmentâs AusLink network? It has the funds. With an extra $13.6 billion surplus and $14 billion collected this year in fuel excise, money cannot be the excuse. The community expect better than the political point scoring they have seen go on where the federal government just says, âWell, itâs the state governmentâs responsibility and they must fund the upgrade.â They cannot do it unless they do it in partnership with the federal government. I urge PHocus and the NRMA to continue their splendid lobbying efforts so that both the government and the opposition understand the urgency of the situation. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThe Australian government has embarked upon one of the most significant reforms to our family law system in 30 years. Some of the changes are well overdue, and I have been most outspoken about them. I think all members of the House would have experienced the residual pain of meeting with a separated or divorced father who is being denied access to his children, or a single mother fighting to get reasonable child support from an absent father. In my experience there is nothing like a family breakdown to bring out the extreme passions in the people involvedâmother, father, grandparents, child and family friends. Family relationship problems have a long-term effect on children, parents and grandparents and are often the start of an intergenerational pattern of broken relationships. Many of the social problems we see today stem from broken homes. It seems to me that most of these problems are the remnants of the animosity which develops during the breakdown of a relationship or the tensions that arise when trying to comply with Family Court orders.

speech.para: The government should be commended for taking the huge step of reforming the family law system. The size of the task is evidenced by the sheer number of submissions made to the former Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairsâand I acknowledge the member for Throsby, who made a big contribution to their report on this issue. I acknowledge her very incisive questioning of witnesses, one of whom was me. The name of the report was Every picture tells a story: report on the inquiry into child custody arrangements in the event of family separation. More than 1,700 submissions were made to the committee and, as I said, I was one of those who made a submission. Members of parliament usually do not do that, but I think this called for a break in the normal protocols. There were 21 public hearings throughout Australia, and I commend the committee for its thoroughness.

Some sections of society say that government have gone too far with these reforms, while others believe we have not gone far enough. Perhaps I am in the latter camp. However, I think it is fair to say that some good things have stemmed from the committeeâs final report, including the roll-out of 65 family relationship centres around Australia. This initiative is part of the governmentâs $397 million family law reform package, the biggest investment made by the government in Australiaâs family law system.

Bundaberg was fortunate to be named as one of the sites of these new centres, and the news has been warmly received in the city. The centre will come on line within the next two years, and I know local families will certainly benefit from the extra support and assistance the centre will provide. It will be a vital resource for families in Bundaberg and the surrounding regions, and I will be working closely with family support professionals, and whoever gets the contract, to ensure that the service is established as soon as possible. The centre will become the first port of call when people want to strengthen their relationships or when they need support when a significant family relationship ends. Essentially, it will be the front door to a new family law system and will be there to support families by strengthening family relationships, preventing separation where possible and enabling parents to resolve post-separation conflict, in the interests of their children.

The centre will also be a valuable resource for couples seeking premarital guidance and for those members of the extended family, such as grandparents, who are often the invisible victims of the breakdown. We want to help create a non-combative environment where parents are encouraged to sit down together and sort out what is best for their children. So, rather than focusing on parental disputes, these centres will redirect attention to the needs and the future of children.

I would like to acknowledge the assistance and encouragement I received in this from the Salvation Army in Bundaberg, and particularly from Tom Quinn himself, after whom their Tom Quinn Centre is named. Tom is a former Qantas corporate planner and now a barrister who does a lot of pro bono work for people in these situations. It was his suggestion that we chase one of these centres. As I really wanted one for my electorate, I complied. By using innovative systems like this, I think we can make a better lifestyle for people. I congratulate the government. I thank Tom and his centre. Of course, Tom and his people will have to bid like everyone else when the tender comes up, but I do acknowledge their vision in helping us to get this particular initiative as far as it has gone.

subdebateinfo.title: Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Delegation

talk.start.para: âI rise today to address the chamber on a recent delegation of which I was part: a delegation of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. Apart from me, the delegation included the Hon. Bruce Scott, the Hon. Graham Edwards, the Hon. Bruce Baird, Mr Kim Wilkie, Cameron Thompson, Barry Haase and Senator David Johnston. We visited the Australian forces in the Middle East last week. The purpose of my address today is to outline briefly what we were about.

speech.para: Our purpose was to visit the Australian armed forces personnel who are deployed in the Middle East area of operations. We visited a number of places, including Dubai, where we were met by the commander of Joint Task Force 633, Commodore Geoff Ledger. From there, we visited HMAS Newcastle and the P3C Orions. From Dubai, we flew to Kuwait. In Kuwait, we visited the Australian force logistical asset at Ali Al Saleem airbase in Kuwait. From there, we flew to TalilâAliâairbase in the south of Iraq and travelled by road to Camp Smitty in the Al Muthanna province, where we had a very important and, I might say, informative time with the Al Muthanna Task Group, commanded by Lieutenant Colonel Roger Noble. We had briefings there, as well as from Lieutenant Colonel Roger Noble, from Major Mick Garraway, who is the commander of Combat Team Tiger, and from Major Mick Bye, who is the commander of Combat Team Eagle. We visited with the Australian troops there, and I must say that it was a very informative and educational experience.

From there we flew by Black Hawk helicopter, with Apache gun ships as escorts, to Baghdad, where we stopped at the Baghdad international zone. We met with a range of people including the Australian ambassador. At Al Muthanna, we had previously met with the Governor of the Al Muthanna province. In the international zone we met with the Australian ambassador, as well as the military adviser to the UN special representative, Colonel Michael Tucker, and Colonel John Mansell, the defence attache. Howard Brown is the ambassador. I must say that he works under a great deal of duress, but he is well looked after by a security detachment of in excess of 100 Australian Defence Force personnel. But I need to point out how dangerous their job is.

From there we travelled to Camp Victory, again by Black Hawk helicopter, to meet with the Australian personnel there at Al Faw Palace. We met again with the Australian personnel under the command of Commodore Ledger, as well as General Casey, who is the commander of the US contingent and of the multinational force in Iraq.

It is not my intention to go through all of the detail of this visit, but I do want to outline a couple of points which I think are most important. The first is that we should have great confidence in the work that our Defence Force personnel are doing. They are very professional. They are highly motivated, very well trained and extremely well led, and they need to be congratulated on the difficult task which they are doing and which they are doing well.

The second is the lessons which we should learn, one of which is that, as became very clear to us, the insurgency-insurrection will not be under control for at least five years. This is a quagmire that Australia should not continue its involvement in, in my view, and we should be looking for an exit strategyâwhich the government appears reluctant to give us. But it seems to me that we do not need to deploy a new rotation of troops to Al Muthanna after the next rotation, which commences duty almost as I speak and will be finished by May. It would be very surprising indeed to me if we needed to deploy troops to Al Muthanna again after that date. So there is an obligation on this government to tell the Australian community what its exit strategy from Iraq is, and it should do it today. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI rise very reluctantly today to have to address a matter which has arisen both in the House and in my electorate of Bass. May I preface all of my remarks today by saying that, while I will be critiquing some of the statements which have been made about me by members of the Labor Party in this place and in Tasmania, I do not seek in any way to bash up the Labor Party. This is correcting the record. I also have to say that honesty, truthful debate and telling the truth to the electors of Australia and of individual membersâ own constituencies, such as mine in Bass, are much more important, much more valuable, than my or any other memberâs individual reputation. People deserve the truth. In correcting the record, I do it in that spirit rather than trying to defend my honour. Having said that, I think it is disgraceful the way that the member for Sydney and others have twisted and writhed in quoting and, I would say, misquoting me and my remarks in the chamber.

speech.para: It goes to a speech that I was making in the House with regard to student services. Having digressed from the key parts of the bill, which were actually dealing with educational services for overseas students, I began to address some of my remarks to VSU. The speaker prior to me was the member for Jagajaga, who had made a good effort in her discrediting of the Minister for Education, Science and Training and in making an attack on the governmentâs case for voluntary student unionism. In responding to her remarks, I mentioned that many services on campus should not be regarded as essential so far as student unions are concerned. I added that child care is an important service. The member for Sydney quoted me in a media release the following day as saying:

quote.para: Child care is not essential ...

speech.para: In quoting me she suggests that this is the Liberalsâ simple view and that it is my simple viewâwhich is wrong. The actual full exchange as reported by Hansard was as follows. I said:

quote.para: ... I will not go through the list of services, or so-called services, but some of them are very dubious indeed. Some of them are worth while, but I would not say that any of them are essential. I have said that in this place in the past. They might be important but to say that they are essential is political rhetoric, and I do not support that.
Mr GarrettâChild care is not essential?
Mr MICHAEL FERGUSONâChild care is not essentialâcorrect. I have said that in the past.
Â Dr Emerson interjectingâ
Mr MICHAEL FERGUSONâI have said it before but you have never quoted me. Child careâand do not misquote meâ
Dr EmersonâItâs only a matter of time.
â¦Â Â Â Â Â Â â¦Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â â¦
Mr MICHAEL FERGUSONâChild care is important, but for you to tell me that a student union must provide child care as an essential service is wrong. Write it down.

speech.para: There was a point of order from Mr Garrett, and I went on to say:

quote.para: Mr MICHAEL FERGUSONâI would invite the member for Rankin to write my quotes down, if he will. He also ought to be aware that in Launceston, in the electorate of Bass, the student union does not run the child-care facility; the university does. Do not tell me that it is essential for the university union to be providing these services. Get your facts straight and be careful what you say.

speech.para: They were not careful with what they then said. The problem with the Labor Party today is that they are still on the nipple of the union movement. They cannot be separated from it, and their symbiotic relationship prevents them from engaging in an honest debate. They do not play the issue; they play the man. They did not attack what I said in the context of the debate by providing all of the quotes from a 3,000-word speech; instead, they attacked me. Why? It is simple, reallyâbecause I am a marginal seat member and they think I am vulnerable. They want to attack me, try and drive the wedge into some cracks and try to convince the community that I do not care about families, children and working mothers. They quoted just five words from my 3,000-word speech and then whipped up concern in the community.

I have understandably had members of the community contacting me in my office expressing concern at what they have been told. I do not blame them; I would be concerned, too, if I had been lied to in that fashion. There is a lot more I could say. I finish as I started, and that is to say that the people of Bass deserve to know the truthâto not be lied toâand that takes pre-eminence over my reputation. This does the Labor Party and the union movement no credit whatsoever. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI say to the member for Bass: welcome to the federal parliament. The simple fact of the matter is that you would have been better advised to make a misrepresentation speech in the House rather than condemn yourself out of your own mouth, which you have done over the last five minutes.

speech.para: I am here today to speak about a significant matter of concern to those in my electorate who are Australian Vietnamese. They are undertaking a campaign, together with other members of the Vietnamese community in Australiaâfrom Sydney, Melbourne, Canberra and elsewhereâin regard to a propaganda campaign that is being run by the communist government of Vietnam. The Vietnamese government has determined that Vietnamese news programs that are offered to institutions like the SBS in Australia, and to other broadcasting companies worldwide, while effectively being offered on a free basis to those who use it, should be an arm of the Vietnamese governmentâs propaganda program.

The intent of that program is to specifically and deliberately break up opposition to the communist government of Vietnam within the Vietnamese diaspora in Australia, America and elsewhere. It aims to set children against parents, grandchildren against grandparents, with a view to establishing a better position for and a more favourable view of the communist government of Vietnam within those groups of refugees who fled Vietnam after the end of the war in 1975 and those communities over the past 30 years who have made a substantial and significant contribution to Australian life.

During the dinner break on Monday night, I spoke at a rally outside a theatre in Canberra. The core point I made was simply this: the communist Vietnamese government have determined to spend $125 million in pursuit of this propaganda campaign to try to disrupt communities overseas and push them out of the way. The Vietnamese government want those communities to no longer campaign against those things happening in Vietnam that affect the human rights of people living in Vietnam and affect the families of people in Australia. There are communities in Vietnam which have had their lives ripped to pieces. Buddhist priests and monks and Catholic priests have been jailed in Vietnam. The civil rights of those people have been trampled into the dust.

I am very proud that the Vietnamese people in my electorate, who have campaigned long and hard in this regard, were entirely successful in getting SBS Television to stop screening the communist news program. That was a significant achievement. For their beliefs in democracy, in their own community and in the freedoms that we have in Australia to pursue a democratic society and for the democratisation of Vietnam, they are willing to stand up and make their voice heard. One of the key elements they have put very strongly in this current campaign, which is very important, is that the government needs to undertake a review of our foreign aid to Vietnam. I ask at this point, as I did on Monday night, that the government do so. The reasoning is very simple. We give significant aid to Vietnam, which we expect to go to foreign aid projects of the quality and calibre that we produce world wide to improve the lives of ordinary people, to help develop the country, to provide clean water and access to services, to help in the democratisation of the society and in the improvement of its governance. But we can have no absolute guarantee, given the behaviour of the communist government in Vietnam, that they are using those moneys properly when they have allocated $125 million to this propaganda campaign. I ask the minister whether he will institute a review into Australiaâs foreign aid to Vietnam. It is right for my community to stand up and speak for the truth. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âSome members of this House may know that I have been urging and fighting for some time for the Perth to Bunbury highway, sometimes known as the Peel deviation, sometimes known as the Mandurah bypass. Since being elected as the member for Canning I have been fighting to get this funded from federal government programs. Under the AusLink program, we originally committed $150 million, then an extra $20 million, which took it to $170 million. That was the federal governmentâs component of the program, because the state government, under Minister Alannah MacTiernan, said that was its costâ$170 million. However, we now know that the minister has suddenly changed her mind and said that the cost of this project is an extra $110 million. That is less than 12 months after announcing it was $340 million. Lo and behold, the other day, in deciding whether or not she would sign the AusLink bilateral agreement, she said it could be another $100 million. These are figures that she plucks out of the air as estimates. She wants us to believe that the federal government should be paying 50 per cent for her cost blow-outs and bogus costings. She does not have any figures and she has not done any real tendering or evaluation of the costs at all. She has an ambit claim, which she says is just an estimate, so how can the federal government sign on to that?

speech.para: What alarms me is that Minister MacTiernan now wants to break the construction of the highway into two stages. This is her way of trying to leverage the federal government to pay her extorted extra $55 million and maybe an extra $110 million. She has put out through Main Roads WA an expression of interest for the building of the first stage rather than for the continuous buildâwhich I am obviously lobbying for, because it is the only sensible thing to do, rather than have a road ending in suburban or rural streets and then costing $30 million in associated roadworks as a temporary measure. She announced that proposals were received for the construction of this highway from three groupsâGateway Alliance, PeelLink and SouthernGateway Consortium. What she did not say was that all the companies that are assigned to these bids come out of the stable of Leighton Holdings. Gateway Alliance includes Thiess and Clough. Thiess is a totally owned subsidiary of Leighton. PeelLink includes John Holland, a partly or wholly owned operation of Leighton. And the SouthernGateway Consortium is headed by Leighton. How do you get a competitive tender for a program when the three companies bidding are basically out of the Leighton stable?

If the minister were serious about having a competitive tender for this project, rather than this bogus type tendering and alliance project that she has put together through the Main Roads Commissioner, Menno Henneveld, she would allow smaller contractors to be involved in either design or construct work or she would have some other form of competitive tendering where you allow smaller contractors such as R4- and R5-rated people, or even a company like BGC, which is R5-rated but cannot bid for a job for more than $50 million. It is a wanton waste of public moneys on infrastructure spending when you do not allow a proper competitive bidding process. The minister did this on the Tonkin Highway, which I exposed in this place several years ago. Through the same subsidiaries of Leighton, the cost blew out from $110 million to $140 million. As a result, who picked up the tab? The Australian taxpayers and the public of Western Australia picked up the tab for both her and Menno Henneveldâs exercise in awarding it to the big end of townâto multinationals companies rather than local companies.

If Minister MacTiernan were serious about a competitive tender on this project she would look at more competitive and more creative ways of getting this road built, as has been done in the past with Roe Highway et cetera, rather than allow this extortive behaviour, which is obviously from Labor mates in Leighton Holdings who allow it to trickle through to their companies, getting the worst possible result for the building of this road. She is not serious about building the road. We know that, because she is trying to delay it for as long as she can. If she were serious, she would try to get the best value for money for this road rather than the extortion that she is involved in now. (Time expired)
